quizquestion.explanation: The autoclitic occurs when a speaker’s own verbal behavior functions as an SD or an MO for additional speaker verbal behavior. The speaker is the listener and observer. (Skinner, 1957)

quizquestion.question: The BCBA says “what time do you go to sleep?” The child responds “8” This is an example of which verbal operant?
quizquestion.explanation: The intraverbal is under the functional control of a verbal SD. The SD and verbal operant do not have point-to-point correspondence. This operant results in generalized conditioned reinforcement. (Skinner, 1957)

quizquestion.question: The mother says “it’s 8pm, it’s time to go to sleep!” The child goes into bed. The mother’s verbal behavior is an example of which verbal operant?
quizquestion.explanation: The mand is under control of motivating operations and results in specific reinforcement. (Skinner, 1957)

quizquestion.question: Prior to conducting intraverbal training, the child should have a substantial repertoire of which behaviors?
quizquestion.explanation: Prior to conducting intraverbal training, the child should have a substantial repertoire of mand, tact, echoic, imitation, receptive, and matching to sample. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Prior to conducting intraverbal training, the child should have a substantial repertoire of which behaviors:
quizquestion.explanation: Prior to conducting intraverbal training, the child should have a substantial repertoire of mand, tact, echoic, imitation, receptive, and matching to sample. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Early intraverbal training should teach simple responses, such as:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Fill in the blank songs “twinkle twinkle little ______”
quizquestion.explanation: one of the most common mistakes made with early intraverbal training is starting with too complex of responses. Fill in the blank songs and activities is a good place to start. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Jonah is thirsty. The BCBA just started conducting mand to intraverbal training. The BCBA says “You drink_____” and shows Jonah a water bottle.  Jonah says “water”. What reinforcer should be provided?
quizquestion.explanation: In intraverbal training, it can be good to start with a mand to condition the verbal stimulus (e.g., “you drink____”) as the SD. The reinforcement should start out with the specific item until the verbal stimulus has been conditioned as the SD. Then Praise, or other GCR should be provided. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: While conducting intraverbal training, Jonah is not thirsty, but has reliably filled in the blank correctly to “you drink_____”. The BCBA says “you drink____” and Jonah replies “water”. What reinforcer should be provided?
quizquestion.explanation: In intraverbal training, it can be good to start with a mand to condition the verbal stimulus (e.g., “you drink____”) as the SD. The reinforcement should start out with the specific item until the verbal stimulus has been conditioned as the SD. Then Praise, or other GCR should be provided. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Use listener training

quizquestion.question: Which of the following may be considered expressive language skills?
quizquestion.explanation: The mand, tact and echoic are all examples of expressive language skills. (Petursdottir, Carr, Lechago, & Almason, 2008)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following may be considered receptive language skills?
quizquestion.explanation: listener responding is a form of receptive language, where the listener emits motor responses to verbal stimuli. (Petursdottir, Carr, Lechago, & Almason, 2008)

quizquestion.question: A boy says “water” and his mother brings him some water. The boy’s behavior, is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: The mand is under control of motivating operations and results in specific reinforcement. (Skinner, 1957)

quizquestion.question: This type of behavior occurs when the listener emits motor responses to verbal stimuli:
quizquestion.explanation: listener responding is a form of receptive language, where the listener emits motor responses to verbal stimuli. (Petursdottir, Carr, Lechago, & Almason, 2008)

quizquestion.question: A boy says “water” and his mother brings him some water. The mother’s behavior, is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: listener responding is a form of receptive language, where the listener emits motor responses to verbal stimuli. (Petursdottir, Carr, Lechago, & Almason, 2008)

quizquestion.question: At dinner, Danny says “pass the salt, please”. His sister then passes the salt. Danny says “Thank you.” In this example, “Pass the salt” is an example of what?
quizquestion.explanation: The mand is under control of motivating operations and results in specific reinforcement. (Skinner, 1957)

quizquestion.question: At dinner, Danny says “pass the salt, please”. His sister then passes the salt. Danny says “Thank you.” In this example, the sister’s behavior is an example of what?
quizquestion.explanation: listener responding is a form of receptive language, where the listener emits motor responses to verbal stimuli. (Petursdottir, Carr, Lechago, & Almason, 2008)

quizquestion.question: At dinner, Danny says “pass the salt, please”. His sister then passes the salt. Danny says “Thank you.” In this example, “thank you” is an example of what?
quizquestion.explanation: Listener responding is generally reinforced by generalized conditioned reinforcement such as praise. (Petursdottir, Carr, Lechago, & Almason, 2008)

quizquestion.question: Mary is conducting discrete trials with a young child. She is using errorless learning (least to most prompting) to teach receptive language skills (listener responding). Mary says “fold your arms”, and the child complies. Mary should:
wrongAnswer: Wait for the child to vocalize that the task is complete
quizquestion.explanation: Praise or other GCR is used to reinforce listener responding during listener training.

quizquestion.question: Mary is conducting discrete trials with a young child. She is using errorless learning (least to most prompting) to teach receptive language skills (listener responding). Mary says “fold your arms”, and the child doesn’t move. Mary should:
quizquestion.explanation: least to most prompting suggests that the least intrusive prompt (modeling) should be attempted prior to moving on to more intrusive prompts.

phase.name: Identify punishers

quizquestion.question: This occurs when there is a stimulus change following a behavior, and then there is a decrease if the future frequency of that behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: Punishment occurs when stimulus change immediately follows a response, and decreases the future frequency of that behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This is a stimulus change, which produces a decrease in behavior when it immediately follows a response.
quizquestion.explanation: A punisher is the stimulus change in a punishment procedure. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This is an unpleasant or noxious stimulus.
quizquestion.explanation: An aversive stimulus is an unpleasant or noxious stimulus. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This is a stimulus whose presentation functions as punishment without any learning history
quizquestion.explanation: Unconditioned punisher is a stimulus whose presentation functions as punishment without any learning history. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This is a stimulus whose presentation function as punishment, as a result of a person’s learning history.
quizquestion.explanation: Unconditioned punisher is a stimulus whose presentation functions as punishment as a result of a person’s learning history. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This is a stimulus change that has been paired with numerous forms of unconditioned and conditioned punishers.
quizquestion.explanation: Generalized conditioned punisher is a stimulus change that has been paired with numerous forms of unconditioned and conditioned punishers. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Mary spanks her child for hitting. There is a decrease in hitting behavior in the future. Spanking, in this example, is a:
quizquestion.explanation: A punisher is the stimulus change in a punishment procedure. Since there was a decrease in behavior, we know that punishment occurred. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Mary spanks her child for hitting. There is an increase in hitting behavior in the future. Spanking, in this example, is a:
quizquestion.explanation: Despite pain being an aversive stimulus, there was an INCREASE in hitting in the future. This indicates that spanking functioned as a reinforcer. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: John is reprimanded for spitting. There was a decrease in problem behavior following the reprimand. What procedure took place in this example?
quizquestion.explanation: Punishment occurs when stimulus change immediately follows a response, and decreases the future frequency of that behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: John is reprimanded for spitting. There was an increase in problem behavior following the reprimand. What procedure took place in this example?
quizquestion.explanation: Punishment occurs when stimulus change immediately follows a response, and decreases the future frequency of that behavior. Since there was an increase in spitting, this was an example of reinforcement. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Use positive and negative punishment

quizquestion.question: This occurs when the presentation of a stimulus following a behavior results in a decrease in the frequency of the behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: Positive punishment occurs when the presentation of a stimulus results in a decrease in the frequency of the behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This occurs when the termination of a stimulus following a behavior, results in a decrease in the future frequency of that behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: Negative punishment occurs when the termination of a stimulus following a behavior, results in a decrease in the future frequency of that behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Jerry’s child is cursing. Jerry turns off the TV and delivers a verbal reprimand. There is a decrease in cursing. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: There was a decrease in cursing. This was an example of punishment. There was a removal of stimulus (TV off) and a presentation of stimulus (reprimand), so this is both positive and negative punishment. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Jerry’s child is cursing. Jerry turns off the TV and delivers a verbal reprimand. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: This example doesn’t state if there was a decrease in cursing. We don’t know if punishment occurred. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Jerry’s child is cursing. Jerry turns off the TV and there is a decrease in future cursing. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: There was a decrease in cursing. This was an example of punishment. There was a removal of stimulus (TV off) which indicates this was negative punishment. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Jerry’s child is cursing. Jerry delivers a verbal reprimand. There is a decrease in cursing. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: There was a decrease in cursing. This was an example of punishment. There was a presentation of stimulus (reprimand), so this is positive punishment. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Jerry’s child curses when Jerry is not there, but when Jerry is there no cursing occurs. Jerry appears to be a:
quizquestion.explanation: SDP stands for “Discriminative stimulus for punishment”. Jerry appears to be an SDP. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Rachel is an RBT working with an adolescent boy who engages in boundary violations. Which of the following is an example of a positive punishment procedure that Rachel could implement?
quizquestion.explanation: Contingent exercise involves requiring the individual to do exercise as punishment for a specific behavior. This is an example of positive punishment because requiring exercise is a presentation of a stimulus. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Rachel is an RBT working with an adolescent boy who engages in boundary violations. Which of the following is an example of a negative punishment procedure that Rachel could implement?
quizquestion.explanation: Response cost programs as part of a token economy is an example of negative punishment because it removes the stimulus as punishment for the specific behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This occurs when there is a stimulus change following a behavior, and then there is a decrease if the future frequency of that behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: Punishment occurs when stimulus change immediately follows a response, and decreases the future frequency of that behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Use appropriate parameters and schedules of punishment

quizquestion.question: When implementing a new punishment procedure, it is important to:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Start with punishment of sufficient magnitude
wrongAnswer: Punish only some occurrences of the behavior
Wait to punish until the end of the behavior chain
quizquestion.explanation: When implementing a new punishment procedure, it is important to start with punishment of sufficient magnitude, punish every occurrence of the behavior, use varied punishers, and deliver the punisher as soon as the chain begins. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: When implementing a new punishment procedure, it is important to:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Punish every occurrence of the behavior
wrongAnswer: Start with low intensity punishment first, and gradually increase if necessary
Wait to punish until the end of the behavior chain
quizquestion.explanation: When implementing a new punishment procedure, it is important to start with punishment of sufficient magnitude, punish every occurrence of the behavior, use varied punishers, and deliver the punisher as soon as the chain begins. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: When implementing a new punishment procedure, it is important to:
wrongAnswer: Start with low intensity punishment first, and gradually increase if necessary
Wait to punish until the end of the behavior chain
Punish only some occurrences of the behavior
quizquestion.explanation: When implementing a new punishment procedure, it is important to start with punishment of sufficient magnitude, punish every occurrence of the behavior, use varied punishers, and deliver the punisher as soon as the chain begins. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: When implementing a new punishment procedure it is important to:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Deliver the punisher as soon as the behavior chain begins
wrongAnswer: Punish only some occurrences of the behavior
Start with low intensity punishment first, and gradually increase if necessary
quizquestion.explanation: When implementing a new punishment procedure, it is important to start with punishment of sufficient magnitude, punish every occurrence of the behavior, use varied punishers, and deliver the punisher as soon as the chain begins. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: When implementing a new punishment procedure, DO NOT:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Start with low intensity punishment first, and gradually increase if necessary
wrongAnswer: Deliver the punisher as soon as the behavior chain begins
Punish every occurrence of the behavior
quizquestion.explanation: When implementing a new punishment procedure, it is important to start with punishment of sufficient magnitude, punish every occurrence of the behavior, use varied punishers, and deliver the punisher as soon as the chain begins. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: When implementing a new punishment procedure, DO NOT:
wrongAnswer: Deliver the punisher as soon as the behavior chain begins
Punish every occurrence of the behavior
Start with punishment of sufficient magnitude
quizquestion.explanation: When implementing a new punishment procedure, it is important to start with punishment of sufficient magnitude, punish every occurrence of the behavior, use varied punishers, and deliver the punisher as soon as the chain begins. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: When implementing a new punishment procedure, DO NOT:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Wait to punish until the end of the behavior chain
wrongAnswer: Punish every occurrence of the behavior
Start with punishment of sufficient magnitude
quizquestion.explanation: When implementing a new punishment procedure, it is important to start with punishment of sufficient magnitude, punish every occurrence of the behavior, use varied punishers, and deliver the punisher as soon as the chain begins. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: When implementing a new punishment procedure, DO NOT:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Punish only some occurrences of the behavior
wrongAnswer: Deliver the punisher as soon as the behavior chain begins
Start with punishment of sufficient magnitude
quizquestion.explanation: When implementing a new punishment procedure, it is important to start with punishment of sufficient magnitude, punish every occurrence of the behavior, use varied punishers, and deliver the punisher as soon as the chain begins. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Behavior analysts should:
wrongAnswer: Minimize any risk of harm while using punishment
quizquestion.explanation: Behavior analysts should not shy away from punishment, consider reinforcement before using punishment, and minimize any risk of harm while using punishment. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: When using punishment, behavior analysts should
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Use other interventions such as differential reinforcement.
wrongAnswer: Start with low intensity punishment first, and gradually increase if necessary
Wait to punish until the end of the behavior chain
quizquestion.explanation: Punishment is typically not implemented without other interventions in place such as differential reinforcement. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Use extinction

quizquestion.question: The discontinuing of reinforcement is:
quizquestion.explanation: Extinction is the discontinuing of reinforcement. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: “Reinforcing ONLY those responses that meet a specific criteria and withholding reinforcement from those responses that do not meet the criteria” is:
quizquestion.explanation: Differential reinforcement is reinforcing ONLY those responses that meet a specific criteria and withholding reinforcement from those responses that do not meet the criteria. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Extinction occurs when:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: All reinforcement is withheld for the behavior of interest
wrongAnswer: There is a decrease in behavior
The individual forgets prior learning history
Appetitive stimuli are delivered regardless of the individual’s behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: Extinction occurs when all reinforcement is withheld for the behavior of interest. If done correctly this will result in a decrease in behavior; however, not all decreases in behavior are a result of extinction. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Extinction for behaviors maintained by positive reinforcement occurs by:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Withholding the presentation of appetitive stimuli for the specific behavior
wrongAnswer: The behavior of interest does not produce a removal of an aversive stimulus
Any occurrence of the behavior results in the delivery of aversive stimuli
quizquestion.explanation: Extinction for behaviors maintained by positive reinforcement occurs by withholding the presentation of appetitive stimuli for the specific behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Extinction for behaviors maintained by negative reinforcement occurs by:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: The behavior of interest does not produce a removal of an aversive stimulus
wrongAnswer: masking or removing the sensory consequence
Any occurrence of the behavior results in the delivery of aversive stimuli
Withholding the presentation of appetitive stimuli for the specific behavior
quizquestion.explanation: Extinction for behaviors maintained by negative reinforcement occurs by the behavior of interest not producing a removal of an aversive stimulus. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Extinction for behaviors maintained by automatic reinforcement occurs by:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: masking or removing the sensory consequence
wrongAnswer: Withholding the presentation of appetitive stimuli for the specific behavior
The behavior of interest does not produce a removal of an aversive stimulus
Any occurrence of the behavior results in the delivery of aversive stimuli
quizquestion.explanation: Extinction for behaviors maintained by automatic reinforcement occurs by masking or removing the sensory consequence. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: During extinction, there is typically an immediate increase in the frequency of the response. This is known as:
quizquestion.explanation: Extinct bursts occur when there is an immediate increase in the frequency of the response. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: During extinction, a behavior may decrease to the point that the behavior no longer occurs, then, seemingly out of nowhere, the behavior occurs. This is known as:
quizquestion.explanation: This is known as spontaneous recovery. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: After completing a functional assessment, it was determined that attention maintains Frank’s aggressive behaviors. What would extinction look like?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Withholding attention while Frank engages in aggressive behaviors
wrongAnswer: Not letting Frank get out of tasks while being aggressive
Giving Frank attention all the time, regardless of his behavior
quizquestion.explanation: Extinction needs to match the function of the behavior. In this instance, that would mean withholding attention while Frank engages in aggressive behaviors. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: After completing a functional assessment, it was determined that escape from tasks maintains Frank’s aggressive behaviors. What would extinction look like?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Not letting Frank get out of tasks while being aggressive
wrongAnswer: Limit the amount of tasks given to Frank
Withholding attention while Frank engages in aggressive behaviors
quizquestion.explanation: Extinction needs to match the function of the behavior. In this instance, that would mean not letting Frank get out of tasks while being aggressive. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Use combinations of reinforcement with punishment and extinction

quizquestion.question: Reinforcing responses that meet  specific criteria, and withholding reinforcement for responses that don’t meet the criteria, is defined as:
quizquestion.explanation: Differential reinforcement occurs by reinforcing responses that meet specific criteria, and withholding reinforcement for responses that don’t meet the criteria. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Differential reinforcement combines which procedures?
quizquestion.explanation: Differential reinforcement combines reinforcement and extinction. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: What is a limitation of using extinction without other procedures?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: No alternative behavior is being learned
wrongAnswer: Behavior can’t truly decrease without punishment
It is dangerous for the individual
quizquestion.explanation: Combining extinction with reinforcement procedures allows for alternative behaviors to be learned. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: What is a limitation of using extinction without other procedures?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Possible worsened side effects including elevated extinction bursts and aggression.
wrongAnswer: Behavior can’t truly decrease without punishment
It is dangerous for the individual
quizquestion.explanation: Combining extinction with other procedures may minimize extinction bursts and aggression. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: It has been established that access to edibles maintains John’s angry outbursts. The intervention package is as follows: John is given edibles whenever he asks appropriately. He is not given edibles when he engages in the behavior. If he engages in angry outbursts, John loses 5 minutes of TV time for every episode of the behavior. Which component utilizes extinction?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Not delivering edibles when he engages in the behavior
wrongAnswer: John is given edibles whenever he asks appropriately
He loses 5 minutes of TV time for every episode of the behavior
quizquestion.explanation: Withholding the edibles during problem behavior is the example of extinction.

quizquestion.question: It has been established that access to edibles maintains John’s angry outbursts. The intervention package is as follows: John is given edibles whenever he asks appropriately. He is not given edibles when he engages in the behavior. If he engages in angry outbursts, John loses 5 minutes of TV time for every episode of the behavior. Which component utilizes reinforcement?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: John is given edibles whenever he asks appropriately
wrongAnswer: He loses 5 minutes of TV time for every episode of the behavior
Not delivering edibles when he engages in the behavior
quizquestion.explanation: Given edibles for appropriate behavior utilizes reinforcement, assuming there is an increase in appropriate requests.

quizquestion.question: It has been established that access to edibles maintains John’s angry outbursts. The intervention package is as follows: John is given edibles whenever he asks appropriately. He is not given edibles when he engages in the behavior. If he engages in angry outbursts, John loses 5 minutes of TV time for every episode of the behavior. Which component utilizes punishment?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: He loses 5 minutes of TV time for every episode of the behavior
wrongAnswer: Not delivering edibles when he engages in the behavior
John is given edibles whenever he asks appropriately
quizquestion.explanation: Punishment is utilized by restricting his TV time contingent on the occurrence of his behavior.

quizquestion.question: Mary engages in attempted elopement, which is usually reinforced escaping a task. The intervention package is as follows: If Mary attempts to elope, the RBT continues to request that she complete the task every 2 minutes until completed. Mary is able to request a 15 minute break from the task demand by using break cards. Every time she elopes, the RBT removes a token as part of the token economy in place for Mary. Which component utilizes extinction?
wrongAnswer: Response cost with the token economy
quizquestion.explanation: Extinction is utilized by continuing to prompt task completion.

quizquestion.question: Mary engages in attempted elopement, which is usually reinforced escaping a task. The intervention package is as follows: If Mary attempts to elope, the RBT continues to request that she complete the task every 2 minutes until completed. Mary is able to request a 15 minute break from the task demand by using break cards. Every time she elopes, the RBT removes a token as part of the token economy in place for Mary. Which component utilizes reinforcement?
wrongAnswer: Response cost with the token economy
quizquestion.explanation: Break cards reinforce appropriate requests, assuming we see an increase in break card uses.

quizquestion.question: Mary engages in attempted elopement, which is usually reinforced escaping a task. The intervention package is as follows: If Mary attempts to elope, the RBT continues to request that she complete the task every 2 minutes until completed. Mary is able to request a 15 minute break from the task demand by using break cards. Every time she elopes, the RBT removes a token as part of the token economy in place for Mary. Which component utilizes punishment?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Response cost with the token economy
quizquestion.explanation: The response cost program utilizes punishment, assuming it resulted in a decrease in elopement.

phase.name: Use response independent schedules of reinforcement (i.e., NCR)

quizquestion.question: This is a procedure, in which stimuli with known reinforcing properties are presented on a time based schedule.
quizquestion.explanation: Non-contingent reinforcement occurs when stimuli with known reinforcing properties are presented on a time based schedule. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Is non-contingent reinforcement, actually reinforcement?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: No, it is not contingent on behavior, and does not result in an increase in behavior.
wrongAnswer: Yes, it is the delivery of appetitive stimuli
Yes, it can improve behavior, and is a research based intervention.
quizquestion.explanation: NCR is an effective antecedent intervention, but despite the name, is not actually reinforcement because it does not result in an increase in behavior. It is however the most frequently used term for the procedure. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: NCR is a(n)
quizquestion.explanation: Non-contingent reinforcement is an antecedent intervention. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Before using non-contingent reinforcement to decrease problem behavior, you must:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Establish the function of the behavior of interest
quizquestion.explanation: Before using NCR to decrease problem behavior, you must establish the function of the behavior of interest. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Joseph engages in boundary violations, which is usually reinforced by attention. Using NCR to reduce problem behavior can be done by:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Delivering attention to Joseph every 5 minutes regardless of his behavior
wrongAnswer: Deliver reinforcement to Joseph when he asks appropriately
Do not deliver attention to Joseph when he engages in boundary violations
Send Joseph to time out whenever he engages in boundary violations
quizquestion.explanation: NCR is used in this example by delivering attention to Joseph every 5 minutes regardless of his behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Using NCR may decrease problem behaviors by:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Functioning as an abolishing operation (AO), reducing motivation to engage in the behavior
wrongAnswer: Functioning as an establishing operation, reducing motivation to engage in the behavior
quizquestion.explanation: NCR procedures function as an AO, reducing motivation to engage in the behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Amy engages in aggressive behaviors, usually resulting in getting out of difficult tasks. NCR procedures can be implemented by:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Giving Amy a break from the task every 10 seconds, regardless of her behavior
wrongAnswer: Continuing to prompt task completion when she refuses
Withhold  TV time for aggressive behaviors
quizquestion.explanation: Giving Amy non-contingent breaks is the correct way to implement NCR in this example. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is a disadvantage to NCR procedures?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: NCR may reduce motivation to engage in adaptive behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: NCR may reduce motivation to engage in adaptive behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is a disadvantage to NCR procedures?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: It may disrupt the instruction process (NCR escape)
quizquestion.explanation: NCR may disrupt the instructional process. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is an advantage to NCR procedures?
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above are correct. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Use differential reinforcement

quizquestion.question: This type of differential reinforcement, delivers reinforcement contingent on the absence of behavior during a set amount of time.
wrongAnswer: Differential reinforcement of low rates of behavior (DRL)
quizquestion.explanation: DRO delivers reinforcement contingent on the absence of behavior during a set amount of time. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Tom receives praise every time he does not hit his head for 30 seconds. Praise is withheld if Tom engages in hitting his head. Which type of differential reinforcement is this?
wrongAnswer: Differential reinforcement of low rates of behavior (DRL)
quizquestion.explanation: DRO delivers reinforcement contingent on the absence of behavior during a set amount of time. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This type of differential reinforcement withholds reinforcement for inappropriate responses, and delivers reinforcement for more acceptable and functionally equivalent behavior.
wrongAnswer: Differential reinforcement of low rates of behavior (DRL)
Differential reinforcement of high rates of behavior (DRH)
quizquestion.explanation: DRA withholds reinforcement for inappropriate responses, and delivers reinforcement for more acceptable and functionally equivalent behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: The BCBA pays attention to Tom every time he requests for attention appropriately. Every time Tom engages in boundary violations, the BCBA ignores Tom. This is an example of:
wrongAnswer: Differential reinforcement of low rates of behavior (DRL)
Differential reinforcement of high rates of behavior (DRH)
quizquestion.explanation: DRA withholds reinforcement for inappropriate responses, and delivers reinforcement for more acceptable and functionally equivalent behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This type of differential reinforcement reinforces behavior that is topographically incompatible with the behavior of interest, while withholding reinforcement for inappropriate behavior.
wrongAnswer: Differential reinforcement of low rates of behavior (DRL)
Differential reinforcement of high rates of behavior (DRH)
quizquestion.explanation: DRI reinforces behavior that is topographically incompatible with the behavior of interest, while withholding reinforcement for inappropriate behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Tom wears a glove on his hand to mask the sensation of slapping his own head. He is reinforced for holding a toy firmly with both hands. Which type of differential reinforcement is this?
wrongAnswer: Differential reinforcement of low rates of behavior (DRL)
Differential reinforcement of high rates of behavior (DRH)
quizquestion.explanation: DRI reinforces behavior that is topographically incompatible with the behavior of interest, while withholding reinforcement for inappropriate behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This type of differential reinforcement delivers reinforcement when the behavior successively decreases in rates of responding.
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Differential reinforcement of low rates of behavior (DRL)
wrongAnswer: Differential reinforcement of high rates of behavior (DRH)
quizquestion.explanation: DRL delivers reinforcement when the behavior successively decreases in rates of responding. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Tom washes his hands 40 times an hour on average. The BCBA reinforces successively longer IRTs of washing his hands. This is an example of:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Differential reinforcement of low rates of behavior (DRL)
wrongAnswer: Differential reinforcement of high rates of behavior (DRH)
quizquestion.explanation: DRL delivers reinforcement when the behavior successively decreases in rates of responding. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This type of differential reinforcement delivers reinforcement when the behavior successively increases in rates of responding.
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Differential reinforcement of high rates of behavior (DRH)
wrongAnswer: Differential reinforcement of low rates of behavior (DRL)
quizquestion.explanation: DRH delivers reinforcement when the behavior successively increases in rates of responding. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Tom only washes his hands once each day. The BCBA reinforces successively more frequent washing of hands, until it reaches a more acceptable rate. This is an example of:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Differential reinforcement of high rates of behavior (DRH)
wrongAnswer: Differential reinforcement of low rates of behavior (DRL)
quizquestion.explanation: DRH delivers reinforcement when the behavior successively increases in rates of responding. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Use interventions based on manipulation of antecedents, such as motivating operations and discriminative stimuli

quizquestion.question: This is defined as a stimulus that signals the availability of reinforcement.
quizquestion.explanation: An SD is defined as a stimulus that signals the availability of reinforcement. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This is defined as an environmental variable that alters the reinforcing or punishing value of a stimulus.
quizquestion.explanation: Motivation operations (MOs) are defined as environmental variables that alter the reinforcing or punishing value of a stimulus. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This is defined as an environmental variable that decreases the value of a reinforcing or punishing stimulus.
quizquestion.explanation: Abolishing operation (AO) is defined as an environmental variable that decreases the value of a reinforcing or punishing stimulus. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This is defined as an environmental variable that increases the reinforcing or punishing value of a stimulus.
quizquestion.explanation: Establish operation (EO) is defined as an environmental variable that increases the reinforcing or punishing value of a stimulus. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This is defined as any environmental condition or stimulus change that occurs before the behavior of interest.
quizquestion.explanation: Antecedent is defined as any environmental condition or stimulus change that occurs before the behavior of interest. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Stacy is hungry and sees a vending machine down the hall. Stacy walks over to the vending machine and purchases a candy bar. Stacy is now full, and does not purchase additional food. Hunger, in this example, is most likely functioning as a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: Hunger in this example, is functioning as an establishing operation. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Stacy is hungry and sees a vending machine down the hall. Stacy walks over to the vending machine and purchases a candy bar. Stacy is now full, and does not purchase additional food. Being full, in this example, is most likely functioning as a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: Being full is functioning as an abolishing operation (AO). (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Stacy is hungry and sees a vending machine down the hall. Stacy walks over to the vending machine and purchases a candy bar. Stacy is now full, and does not purchase additional food. The sight of the vending machine, in this example, is most likely functioning as a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: The sight of the vending machine is an SD. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: There is a bee flying around Joseph. Joseph grabs a nearby rolled up magazine and swats the bee. The bee leaves. In this example, the bee flying around Joseph is most likely functioning as a(n)
quizquestion.explanation: This can be a tricky one. The bee is functioning as an EO. For negative reinforcement contingencies, the aversive stimulus is typically functioning as an EO for escape. The SD is the magazine. Without the magazine, Joseph wouldn’t have been able to swat at the bee. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: There is a bee flying around Joseph. Joseph grabs a nearby rolled up magazine and swats the bee. The bee leaves. In this example, the magazine is most likely functioning as a(n)
quizquestion.explanation: This can be a tricky one. The magazine is functioning as an SD. For negative reinforcement contingencies, the aversive stimulus is typically functioning as an EO for escape. The SD is the magazine. Without the magazine, Joseph wouldn’t have been able to swat at the bee. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Use discrimination training procedures

quizquestion.question: This is defined as a stimulus that signals the availability of reinforcement.
quizquestion.explanation: An SD is defined as a stimulus that signals the availability of reinforcement. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This is defined as a stimulus that signals the unavailability of reinforcement.
quizquestion.explanation: SΔ (S-Delta) (Stimulus Delta) is defined as a stimulus that signals the unavailability of reinforcement. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Discrimination training is taking place with Alexander, by placing a green sign by the door when outside activities are available. A red sign is on the door when no outside activities are available. In this example, the red sign is functioning as a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: SΔ (S-Delta) (Stimulus Delta) is defined as a stimulus that signals the unavailability of reinforcement. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Discrimination training is taking place with Alexander, by placing a green sign by the door when outside activities are available. A red sign is on the door when no outside activities are available. In this example, the green sign is functioning as a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: An SD is defined as a stimulus that signals the availability of reinforcement. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Discrimination training is taking place with Alexander, by placing a green sign by the door when outside activities are available. A red sign is on the door when no outside activities are available. If Alexander asks to go on an activity very politely while the red sign is out, he should:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Not be allowed to go on the activity
wrongAnswer: Allow the activity, because he asked politely
Implement a punishment procedure to aid in the discrimination process
quizquestion.explanation: Red needs to signal the absence of reinforcement. He should not be allowed to go on the activity any time the red sign is on the door. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This procedure is used to establish an SΔ:
quizquestion.explanation: Extinction is used to establish that a stimulus does not produce reinforcement. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This procedure is used to establish an SD
quizquestion.explanation: Reinforcement is used to establish an SD. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Fred is learning colors with discrimination training. The RBT shows Fred a blue card and displays 3 cards in front of Fred: Blue, Green, and Red. The presentation of blue card functions as a _____ for selecting the blue card and should result in________.
quizquestion.explanation: An SD is defined as a stimulus that signals the availability of reinforcement. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Fred is learning colors with discrimination training. The RBT shows Fred a blue card and displays 3 cards in front of Fred: Blue, Green, and Red. The presentation of the blue card functions as a _____ for selecting the green card and should result in________.
quizquestion.explanation: SΔ (S-Delta) (Stimulus Delta) is defined as a stimulus that signals the unavailability of reinforcement. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Fred is learning colors with discrimination training. The RBT shows Fred a blue card and displays 3 cards in front of Fred: Blue, Green, and Red. The presentation of the blue card functions as a _____ for selecting the red card and should result in________.
quizquestion.explanation: SΔ (S-Delta) (Stimulus Delta) is defined as a stimulus that signals the unavailability of reinforcement. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Use instructions and rules

quizquestion.question: This type of behavior is under control of a verbal statement explaining the contingency. This allows the behavior to be under the control of temporally remote, yet significant consequences.
quizquestion.explanation: Rule governed behavior is under control of a verbal statement explaining the contingency. This allows the behavior to be under the control of temporally remote, yet significant consequences. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This is a verbal statement explaining a behavioral contingency
quizquestion.explanation: A rule is a verbal statement explaining a behavioral contingency. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This type of behavior is selected and maintained by controlled and temporally close consequences.
quizquestion.explanation: Contingency shaped behavior is selected and maintained by controlled and temporally close consequences. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Mary wears her seatbelt even though she has never been in an accident or been pulled over in the car. She has been told that if she gets in an accident she will likely die if she isn’t wearing a seatbelt. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Rule governed behavior is under control of a verbal statement explaining the contingency. This allows the behavior to be under the control of temporally remote, yet significant consequences. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Mary didn’t usually wear a seatbelt. She got pulled over and received a ticket for not wearing her seatbelt. Next time Mary gets in her car, she puts on her seatbelt. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Contingency shaped behavior is selected and maintained by controlled and temporally close consequences. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Mary was told that she should always wear a seatbelt because it will keep her safe in case of an accident. This is an example of a:
quizquestion.explanation: A rule is a verbal statement explaining a behavioral contingency. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: James is told that the vending machine is broken. He remains sitting and does not go attempt to purchase a candy bar, even though he is hungry. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Rule governed behavior is under control of a verbal statement explaining the contingency. This allows the behavior to be under the control of temporally remote, yet significant consequences. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: James goes to the vending machine, and pushes a button to purchase a candy bar. The machine is not working, so James leaves. The next day, James does not try to purchase a candy bar out of the vending machine. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Contingency shaped behavior is selected and maintained by controlled and temporally close consequences. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Frank engages in yelling. He is told that if he yells, he is going to hurt his throat. Frank doesn’t yell the entire day. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Rule governed behavior is under control of a verbal statement explaining the contingency. This allows the behavior to be under the control of temporally remote, yet significant consequences. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Frank engages in yelling. After yelling all day, his throat begins to hurt. Frank stops yelling, and the next day, doesn’t yell nearly as much. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Contingency shaped behavior is selected and maintained by controlled and temporally close consequences. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Use contingency contracting

quizquestion.question: This is defined as a document that specifies a contingent relationship between the completion of a specified behavior and access to a reward.
quizquestion.explanation: A contingency contract (behavioral contract) is a document that specifies a contingent relationship between the completion of a specified behavior and access to a reward. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This is a verbal statement explaining a behavioral contingency
quizquestion.explanation: A rule is a verbal statement explaining a behavioral contingency. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: According to the literature, to create a contingency contract, what level of description is needed?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Descriptively written and signed by both parties
wrongAnswer: At least one party should have it written down
Any rule-governed behavior is considered a contingency contract.
quizquestion.explanation: Contingency contracts (behavioral contracts) need to be descriptively written and signed by both parties. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following should be included in a behavioral contract?
wrongAnswer: A description of the task, or behavior of interest
A description of the reward, including who will deliver it, when it will be delivered, and how much will be given
A place to record progress with the task should be included on the behavioral contract
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above should be included in a behavioral contract. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is not a necessary component of a behavioral contract?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: A detailed title to the behavioral contract
wrongAnswer: None of the above are necessary components
quizquestion.explanation: A detailed title to the behavioral contract is not a necessary component. However, signatures from both parties and a place to record progress are important components. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: With regards to describing the behavior or task in a contingency contract, which of the following questions DO NOT need to be explained?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Why must the task be completed?
wrongAnswer: When must the task be completed?
How well must the task be completed?
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above must be answered in a behavioral contract except for “why must the task be completed?” (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: With regards to describing the reward in a contingency contract, which of the following questions DO NOT need to be explained?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Why was the specific reward chosen?
wrongAnswer: When will the reward be given?
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above must be answered in a behavioral contract except for “why was the specific reward chosen?” (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which principle of behavior is most closely related to how behavioral contracts control behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Behavioral contracts are most related to rule-governed behavior. The reward is too delayed to typically function as positive reinforcement. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: John tells his son that if he goes 5 days in a row completing all of his homework, he will be given $20. Both John and his son agree on this and follow through with the contingency, even though nothing was written down. This contingency is an example of a?
quizquestion.explanation: This is an example of a rule. It is a verbal statement of a contingency. Nothing was written down so there was no behavioral contract. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: John writes down that if his son goes 5 days in a row completing all of his homework, he will be given $20. Specific criteria are outlined as to what exactly the boy needs to do and what the reward will be. John and his son sign this document. This contingency is an example of a?
quizquestion.explanation: The contingency was written down with details laid out. The document was signed. This is an example of a contingency contract. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Use independent, interdependent, and dependent group contingencies

quizquestion.question: This occurs when a common consequence is contingent on the behavior of one member of the group, part of the group, or everyone in the group.
quizquestion.explanation: Group contingencies occur when a common consequence is contingent on the behavior of one member of the group, part of the group, or everyone in the group. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This occurs when a contingency is presented to all members of a group, but only those who meet the criterion receive reinforcement.
quizquestion.explanation: Independent group contingencies occur when a contingency is presented to all members of a group, but only those who meet the criterion receive reinforcement. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This occurs when all members of a group m ust meet the criterion of the contingency before any member earns the reward.
quizquestion.explanation: Interdependent group contingencies occur when all members of a group m ust meet the criterion of the contingency before any member earns the reward. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This occurs when one member (or a few members) meets the established criterion, and then the entire group receives the reward.
quizquestion.explanation: Dependent group contingencies (the hero procedure) occur when one member (or a few members) meets the established criterion, and then the entire group receives the reward. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This procedure is also known as the “hero procedure”.
quizquestion.explanation: Dependent group contingencies (the hero procedure) occur when one member (or a few members) meets the established criterion, and then the entire group receives the reward. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Donna is a teacher and set a procedure in place where anyone in her class who gets over 90% on the spelling test gets an extra 30 minutes of recess.  Which group contingency is in effect?
quizquestion.explanation: Independent group contingencies occur when a contingency is presented to all members of a group, but only those who meet the criterion receive reinforcement. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Donna is a teacher and set a procedure in place that the entire class will get an extra 30 minutes of recess if every student gets over 90% on the spelling test. Which group contingency is in effect?
quizquestion.explanation: Interdependent group contingencies occur when all members of a group must meet the criterion of the contingency before any member earns the reward. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Donna is a teacher and set a procedure in place that the entire class will get an extra 30 minutes of recess if one student gets over 90% on the spelling test. The student’s name is drawn at random just prior to the test.  Which group contingency is in effect?
quizquestion.explanation: Dependent group contingencies (the hero procedure) occur when one member (or a few members) meets the established criterion, and then the entire group receives the reward. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: At a local business, each employee is given a $500 bonus as soon as their individual paperwork is completed and submitted. Any employees who turn in paperwork after the deadline does not receive the reward. Which group contingency is in effect?
quizquestion.explanation: Independent group contingencies occur when a contingency is presented to all members of a group, but only those who meet the criterion receive reinforcement. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: At a local business, each employee is given a $500 bonus only when every employee has completed and submitted their paperwork by the deadline. If one person fails to submit their paperwork, nobody receives the reward.
quizquestion.explanation: Interdependent group contingencies occur when all members of a group must meet the criterion of the contingency before any member earns the reward. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Use stimulus equivalence procedures

quizquestion.question: This is defined as a description of the emergence of accurate responding to untrained and nonreinforced relations following the reinforcement of other relations.
quizquestion.explanation: Stimulus equivalence is a description of the emergence of accurate responding to untrained and nonreinforced relations following the reinforcement of other relations. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This occurs when, in the absence of training, a response will select a stimulus that is matched to itself.
quizquestion.explanation: Reflexivity occurs when in the absence of training a response will select a stimulus that is matched to itself. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: A boy is shown a picture of a dog and the boy selects another picture of a dog (A = A). This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Reflexivity occurs when in the absence of training a response will select a stimulus that is matched to itself. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This occurs with the reversibility of the sample stimulus and comparison stimulus.
quizquestion.explanation: Symmetry occurs with the reversibility of the sample stimulus and comparison stimulus. (if A = B, then B = A). (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: The instructor presents a picture of a dog, and the boy selects a toy dog from an array of toys. The instructor then presents a toy dog, and the boy selects a picture of a dog. (If A = B, then B = A)This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Symmetry occurs with the reversibility of the sample stimulus and comparison stimulus. (if A = B, then B = A). (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This occurs when a derived relation emerges as a product of training two other relations.
quizquestion.explanation: Transitivity occurs when a derived relation emerges as a product of training two other relations. If A = B and B = C, then A = C. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: The instructor demonstrates that the image of the dog and the toy dog are the same. He then teaches that the toy dog and the written word “DOG” are the same. Then, without direct training, the boy selects the written word “DOG” when shown an image of a dog. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Transitivity occurs when a derived relation emerges as a product of training two other relations. If A = B and B = C, then A = C. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: A learner demonstrates that A = A without prior training. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Reflexivity occurs when in the absence of training a response will select a stimulus that is matched to itself. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: If A = B, then B = A. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Symmetry occurs with the reversibility of the sample stimulus and comparison stimulus. (if A = B, then B = A). (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: If A = B and B = C, then A = C. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Transitivity occurs when a derived relation emerges as a product of training two other relations. If A = B and B = C, then A = C. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Plan for behavioral contrast effects

quizquestion.question: This phenomenon occurs when changes in one component of a schedule results in an increase or decrease in the rate of responding but also results in the opposite effect in environments in which the schedule was not changed:
quizquestion.explanation: Behavioral contrast occurs when changes in one component of a schedule results in an increase or decrease in the rate of responding but also results in the opposite effect in environments in which the schedule was not changed. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This occurs when there is a stimulus change following a behavior, and then there is a decrease if the future frequency of that behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: Punishment occurs when stimulus change immediately follows a response, and decreases the future frequency of that behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Mary loses TV time when her mother is home and Mary doesn’t clean her room. Mary usually cleans her room when her mother is home. When her mother is not home, Mary never cleans her room. What effect appears to be occurring?
quizquestion.explanation: Behavioral contrast occurs when changes in one component of a schedule results in an increase or decrease in the rate of responding but also results in the opposite effect in environments in which the schedule was not changed. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Mary loses TV time when her mother is home and Mary doesn’t clean her room. Mary usually cleans her room when her mother is home. When her mother is not home, but her father is home, Mary never cleans her room. Mary’s mother appears to be a(n)?
quizquestion.explanation: Mary’s mother appears to be functioning as an SDP. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Mary loses TV time when her mother is home and Mary doesn’t clean her room. Mary usually cleans her room when her mother is home. When her mother is not home, and her father is home, Mary never cleans her room. Mary’s father appears to be a(n)?
quizquestion.explanation: Mary’s father appears to be functioning as an SΔP. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Behavioral contrast effects can be minimized by:
wrongAnswer: Using the intervention in ALL applicable settings and conditions
Withhold reinforcement for all occurrences of problem behavior
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above can be used to minimize behavioral contrast effects. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Behavioral contrast effects can be minimized by:
wrongAnswer: Ask the person to not engage in the problem behavior
quizquestion.explanation: Behavioral contrast effects can be minimized by providing alternative desirable behaviors. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Don engages in frequent disruptive behaviors. His teacher implements a token economy where she removes one of Don’s tokens every time he is disruptive. This results in disruptive behaviors decreasing while the teacher is there. When a substitute teacher is present, engages in even more frequent disruptive behaviors. What phenomenon is occurring?
quizquestion.explanation: Behavioral contrast occurs when changes in one component of a schedule results in an increase or decrease in the rate of responding but also results in the opposite effect in environments in which the schedule was not changed. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Don engages in frequent disruptive behaviors. His teacher implements a token economy where she removes one of Don’s tokens every time he is disruptive. This results in disruptive behaviors decreasing while the teacher is there. When a substitute teacher is present, engages in even more frequent disruptive behaviors. The teacher appears to be functioning as a(n)?
quizquestion.explanation: Don’s teacher appears to be functioning as an SDP. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Don engages in frequent disruptive behaviors. His teacher implements a token economy where she removes one of Don’s tokens every time he is disruptive. This results in disruptive behaviors decreasing while the teacher is there. When a substitute teacher is present, engages in even more frequent disruptive behaviors. The substitute teacher appears to be functioning as a(n)?
quizquestion.explanation: Don’s substitute teacher appears to be functioning as an SΔP. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Use the matching law and recognize factors influencing choice

quizquestion.question: According to this principle, behavior matches reinforcement distribution.
quizquestion.explanation: According to the matching law, behavior matches reinforcement distribution. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: The matching law explains “choice” within which schedule of reinforcement?
quizquestion.explanation: The matching law explains choice within concurrent schedules of reinforcement. (Martin, Yu, Martin, & Fazzio, 2006)

quizquestion.question: This is defined as the presence of multiple discriminative stimuli.
quizquestion.explanation: A choice is defined as the presence of multiple discriminative stimuli. (Martin, Yu, Martin, & Fazzio, 2006)

quizquestion.question: This is defined as performing a discriminated operant, when another is possible.
quizquestion.explanation: Choosing is defined as performing a discriminated operant, when another is possible. (Martin, Yu, Martin, & Fazzio, 2006)

quizquestion.question: This occurs when one discriminated operant is stronger than another, especially when a choice is present.
quizquestion.explanation: A preference is evident when one discriminated operant is stronger than another, especially when a choice is present. (Martin, Yu, Martin, & Fazzio, 2006)

quizquestion.question: This Compound  schedule of reinforcement occurs when 2 contingencies are operating simultaneously and independently for two or more behaviors. This schedule provides choice for the individual, and occurs frequently in the natural environment.

This Compound schedule of reinforcement occurs when two or more schedules of reinforcement occur in an alternating, usually random sequence. A discriminative stimulus is correlated with each schedule.
quizquestion.explanation: Multiple schedules of reinforcement occur when two or more schedules of reinforcement occur in an alternating, usually random sequence. A discriminative stimulus is correlated with each schedule. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: According to the matching law, what affects choosing?
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above affect choosing. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: According to the matching law, what affects choosing?
quizquestion.explanation: Reinforcement rate affects choosing. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Measuring choice allocation during frequent response opportunities will help determine:
quizquestion.explanation: Measuring choice allocation during frequent response opportunities will help determine preferences. (Martin, Yu, Martin, & Fazzio, 2006)

phase.name: Arrange high-probability request sequences

quizquestion.question: This is defined as a metaphor to describe a rate of responding and its resistance to change following an alteration in reinforcement conditions.
quizquestion.explanation: Behavioral momentum is defined as a metaphor to describe a rate of responding and its resistance to change following an alteration in reinforcement conditions. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This is an antecedent intervention in which two to five easy tasks with a known history of compliance are presented in quick succession immediately before requesting the target task.
quizquestion.explanation: High-probability request sequence is an antecedent intervention in which two to five easy tasks with a known history of compliance are presented in quick succession immediately before requesting the target task. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This is a behavior that has a known history of compliance.
quizquestion.explanation: A high probability behavior is one that has a known history of compliance. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This is a target request in a high-p request sequence.
quizquestion.explanation: The low-probability behavior is the target request in a high-p request sequence. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: To implement a high-p request sequence, the instructor should:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Give 2-5 high-p requests, then one low-p request
wrongAnswer: Give one high-p request, then 2-5 low-p requests
Give 2-5 low-p requests, the one high-p request
Give one low-p request, then 2-5 high-p requests
quizquestion.explanation: To implement a high-p request sequence, the instructor should give 2-5 high-p requests, then one low-p request. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: The tasks selected for the high-p request sequence should:
wrongAnswer: Be in the learner’s current repertoire
Have a short duration of occurrence
quizquestion.explanation: Tasks selected for the high-p request sequence should be in the learner’s current repertoire, have a short duration of occurrence, and occur with regular compliance. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: The tasks selected for the high-p request sequence should:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Be in the learner’s current repertoire
wrongAnswer: Have a long duration of occurrence
quizquestion.explanation: Tasks selected for the high-p request sequence should be in the learner’s current repertoire, have a short duration of occurrence, and occur with regular compliance. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: During a high-p request sequence, after presenting a high-p request, when do you request another?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Immediately following reinforcement for compliance to the first high-p request
wrongAnswer: Immediately following the first high-p request
A while after the first high-p request
A while after reinforcement for compliance to the first high-p request
quizquestion.explanation: Another high-p request should be delivered immediately following reinforcement for compliance to the first high-p request. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: During a high-p request sequence, when do you give a low-p request?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Immediately after the learner complied with 2-5 high-p requests
wrongAnswer: A few minutes after the learner complied with 2-5 high-p requests
Immediately before presenting one high-p request
quizquestion.explanation: The low-p request is to be delivered immediately after the learner complied with 2-5 high-p requests. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: What should be done immediately after complying with a high-p request?
quizquestion.explanation: Immediately after compliance with a high-p request, reinforcement should be delivered, then an additional high-p request. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Use the Premack principle

quizquestion.question: What is another name for the Premack principle?
quizquestion.explanation: Grandma’s law is another name for the Premack principle. (Klatt & Morris, 2001)

quizquestion.question: Any response A will reinforce any response B if and only if the independent rate of A is greater than B. This is the definition of what?
quizquestion.explanation: The Premack principle explains that any response A will reinforce any response B if and only if the independent rate of A is greater than B. (Klatt & Morris, 2001)

quizquestion.question: To implement the Premack principle, the instructor needs to select 2 behaviors. These should be:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: The target behavior to increase and a preferred behavior/activity
wrongAnswer: The target behavior to increase and a preferred item
quizquestion.explanation: To implement the Premack principle, the instructor will select the target behavior to increase and a preferred behavior/activity. (Klatt & Morris, 2001)

quizquestion.question: Joseph struggles to brush his teeth, but he loves to color. To implement the Premack principle:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Joseph should be required to brush his teeth before he is allowed to color.
wrongAnswer: Joseph should be allowed to color as much as he wants, so he isn’t too upset to take a break to brush his teeth.
Joseph should be allowed to color for 10 minutes, and then he must take a break to brush his teeth.
Joseph may color as long as he promises to brush his teeth later.
quizquestion.explanation: Joseph should be required to brush his teeth before he is allowed to color. (Klatt & Morris, 2001)

quizquestion.question: When preferred activities are restricted, this will function as an establishing operation to make them more powerful reinforcers. This is known as:
quizquestion.explanation: The response deprivavtion hypothesis explains that when preferred activities are restricted, this will function as an establishing operation to make them more powerful reinforcers. (Klatt & Morris, 2001)

quizquestion.question: According to the response deprivation hypothesis, the Premack principle will be more effective if which behavior is limited/restricted?
wrongAnswer: Both the less and more preferred behavior/activity
Neither the less nor the preferred behavior/activity
quizquestion.explanation: Restricting the preferred behavior/activity will increase the effectiveness of the Premack principle. (Klatt & Morris, 2001)

quizquestion.question: Lucy loves playing basketball. She does not enjoy doing her homework. To implement the Premack principle, what contingency should be in place?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Lucy must complete her homework before playing basketball.
wrongAnswer: Lucy should complete half of her homework, play basketball for 15 minutes, then finish her homework.
Lucy may play basketball first ONLY if she promises to do her homework after basketball.
Lucy should be allowed to play basketball until she is bored, then she will choose to do her homework on her own.
quizquestion.explanation: Lucy should be required to complete her homework before playing basketball. (Klatt & Morris, 2001)

quizquestion.question: The Premack principle reinforces non-preferred behaviors/activitities with:
wrongAnswer: Any item established as a reinforce
quizquestion.explanation: The Premack principle reinforces non-preferred behaviors/activities with a highly preferred behavior/activity. (Klatt & Morris, 2001)

quizquestion.question: Lucy loves playing basketball. She does not enjoy doing her homework. To use response deprivation to increase the effectiveness of the Premack principle, you should:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Restrict the amount of time Lucy may play basketball
wrongAnswer: Restrict the amount of time Lucy may do homework
Not restrict the amount of time Lucy may play basketball
Not restrict the amount of time Lucy may do homework
quizquestion.explanation: According to the response deprivation hypothesis, restricting the amount of time Lucy plays basketball would help increase the effectiveness of the Premack principle. (Klatt & Morris, 2001)

quizquestion.question: Joseph struggles to brush his teeth, but he loves to color. To use response deprivation to increase the effectiveness of the Premack  principle, you should:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Restrict the amount of time Joseph may color
wrongAnswer: Restrict the amount of time Joseph may brush his teeth
Not restrict the amount of time Joseph may color
Not restrict the amount of time Joseph may brush his teeth
quizquestion.explanation: According to the response deprivation hypothesis, restricting the amount of time Joseph may color would help increase the effectiveness of the Premack principle. (Klatt & Morris, 2001)

phase.name: Use pairing procedures to establish new conditioned reinforcers and punishers

quizquestion.question: The contingent presentation of this stimulus increases a behavior due to the individual’s learning history.
quizquestion.explanation: This is a conditioned reinforce. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: The contingent presentation of this stimulus increases a behavior NOT due to the individual’s learning history.
quizquestion.explanation: This is an unconditioned reinforcer. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: The contingent presentation of this stimulus decreases a behavior due to the individual’s learning history.
quizquestion.explanation: This is a conditioned punisher. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: The contingent presentation of this stimulus decreases a behavior NOT due to the individual’s learning history.
quizquestion.explanation: This is an unconditioned punisher. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: The contingent presentation of this stimulus does not increase nor decrease behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: This is a neutral stimulus. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Small edible treats is reinforcing for James, however praise is not. What process should take place to help Praise become a conditioned reinforcer?
quizquestion.explanation: Stimulus-stimulus pairing (or just “pairing”) should take place. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Small edible treats is reinforcing for James, however praise is not. How can praise become a conditioned reinforcer?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Deliver praise as temporally close to delivering small edibles as possible.
wrongAnswer: Pair praise with a conditioned punisher
quizquestion.explanation: Deliver praise as temporally close to delivering small edibles as possible. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This powerful stimulus has been paired with several different reinforcers to gain reinforcing properties.
quizquestion.explanation: This is a generalized conditioned reinforcer. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: For most people, money is a powerful reinforcer because it has been paired with many other reinforcers. This is an example of a:
quizquestion.explanation: This is a generalized conditioned reinforcer. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Praise was paired repeatedly with small edibles. However, when praise is delivered alone, it still does not increase the frequency of the behavior. Praise appears to be functioning as a:
quizquestion.explanation: Praise appears to be functioning as a neutral stimulus in this example. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Use errorless learning procedures

quizquestion.question: Which of the following may be used in an errorless learning procedure?
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above are errorless learning procedures.

quizquestion.question: Which of the following may be used in an errorless learning procedure?
quizquestion.explanation: Response prompts may be used in an errorless learning procedure.
