quizquestion.question: This teaching strategy is based on the understanding that trial and error is not a necessary part of learning.
quizquestion.explanation: Errorless learning is based on the understanding that trial and error is not a necessary part of learning.

quizquestion.question: This errorless learning procedure gradually increases the amount of time from the SD to the response prompt.
quizquestion.explanation: Time delay procedures gradually increase the amount of time from the SD to the response prompt.

quizquestion.question: This errorless learning procedure may involve modeling, physical prompting, and verbal instructions.
quizquestion.explanation: Response prompts involve modeling, physical prompting, and verbal instructions.

quizquestion.question: This errorless learning procedure involves highlighting a physical dimension of a stimulus (color, size, position) to increase the likelihood of a correct response. This is then gradually faded.
quizquestion.explanation: This is an example of stimulus fading.

quizquestion.question: Alex is a BCBA using errorless learning to teach a child to discriminate between red and pink. After saying “Where is the red card?” he places his hand on hers, moving her hand until she selects the correct card. This is an example of which kind of prompt?
quizquestion.explanation: Full physical prompts include hand over hand manipulation to aid the learner to the correct answer.

quizquestion.question: Alex is a BCBA using errorless learning to teach a child to discriminate between red and pink. After saying “Where is the red card?” Alex touches the correct response, demonstrating the correct response. This is an example of which kind of prompt?
quizquestion.explanation: Modeling includes the instructor demonstrating the correct response for the learner.

quizquestion.question: Alex is a BCBA using errorless learning to teach a child to discriminate between red and pink. After saying “Where is the red card?” Alex points in the direction of the correct card. This is an example of which kind of prompt?
quizquestion.explanation: Gestural prompts include pointing or gesturing towards the next step of completing the task.

quizquestion.question: Alex is a BCBA using errorless learning to teach a child to discriminate between red and ink. After saying “Where is the red card?” Alex immediately points in the direction of the correct card. During the next trial, Alex waits 1 second before giving another prompt. Alex appears to be using which errorless learning procedure?
quizquestion.explanation: Alex appears to be using a time delay.

phase.name: Use matching to sample procedures

quizquestion.question: Matching to sample procedures are used to help develop and test for:
quizquestion.explanation: Matching to sample procedures are used to help develop and test for stimulus equivalence.

quizquestion.question: Matching to sample procedures usually take place in:
quizquestion.explanation: Matching to sample procedures usually take place in discrete trials.

quizquestion.question: A boy is shown a picture of a dog and the boy selects another picture of a dog (A = A). This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Reflexivity occurs when in the absence of training a response will select a stimulus that is matched to itself. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: The instructor presents a picture of a dog, and the boy selects a toy dog from an array of toys. The instructor then presents a toy dog, and the boy selects a picture of a dog. (If A = B, then B = A)This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Symmetry occurs with the reversibility of the sample stimulus and comparison stimulus. (if A = B, then B = A). (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: The instructor demonstrates that the image of the dog and the toy dog are the same. He then teaches that the toy dog and the written word “DOG” are the same. Then, without direct training, the boy selects the written word “DOG” when shown an image of a dog. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Transitivity occurs when a derived relation emerges as a product of training two other relations. If A = B and B = C, then A = C. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This is defined as a description of the emergence of accurate responding to untrained and nonreinforced relations following the reinforcement of other relations.
quizquestion.explanation: Stimulus equivalence is a description of the emergence of accurate responding to untrained and nonreinforced relations following the reinforcement of other relations. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: These are procedures used to test for stimulus equivalence:
quizquestion.explanation: Matching to sample procedures test for stimulus equivalence.

quizquestion.question: The instructor demonstrates that the image of the dog and the toy dog are the same. He then teaches that the toy dog and the written word “DOG” are the same. Then, without direct training, the boy selects the written word “DOG” when shown an image of a dog. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Transitivity occurs when a derived relation emerges as a product of training two other relations. If A = B and B = C, then A = C. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: A learner demonstrates that A = A without prior training. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Reflexivity occurs when in the absence of training a response will select a stimulus that is matched to itself. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: If A = B and B = C, then A = C. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Transitivity occurs when a derived relation emerges as a product of training two other relations. If A = B and B = C, then A = C. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Use self-management strategies

quizquestion.question: This is defined as the personal application of behavior change tactics that produces a desired change in behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: Self-Management is the correct answer. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Why is “Self-Control” a misleading term?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: It implies that the ultimate control of behavior lies within the person.
wrongAnswer: It implies that people can influence their own behavior.
It implies that behavior is able to be controlled.
It implies that behavior cannot be controlled.
quizquestion.explanation: The term “self-control” is misleading because it implies that the ultimate control of behavior lies within the person. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is an advantage of using self-management strategies?
wrongAnswer: It can influence behaviors not accessible to external change agents
People with diverse abilities can learn these skill
quizquestion.explanation: All of the answers above are correct. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is an advantage of using self-management strategies?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Self-Management is an ultimate goal of education
wrongAnswer: Only higher functioning individuals are capable of learning these skills
quizquestion.explanation: Self-Management is an ultimate goal of education. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is an antecedent based self-management strategy?
wrongAnswer: Removing materials required for an undesired behavior
Limiting an undesired behavior to restricted stimulus conditions
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is an antecedent based self-management strategy?
quizquestion.explanation: Providing environmental prompts/cues is an antecedent based self-management strategy. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: To prevent yourself from purchasing too much food at the grocery store, you eat a big meal right before you go shopping. What type of self-management strategy are you using?
wrongAnswer: Removing materials required for an undesired behavior
Limiting an undesired behavior to restricted stimulus conditions.
quizquestion.explanation: By getting full before shopping, you are manipulating MOs. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: You discover you say the word “like” too often during conversation. Every time you say “like” you mark a tally on a little notebook you carry around. What type of self-management strategy are you using?
wrongAnswer: Removing materials required for an undesired behavior
Performing the initial steps of a behavior chain
quizquestion.explanation: This is an example of self-monitoring. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: You struggle to go to the gym in the morning, and often sleep through the alarm. You pack your gym bag the night before and place it by the door in the morning to make it easier to go the next day. What type of self-management strategy are you using?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Performing initial steps of a behavior chain
wrongAnswer: Removing materials required for an undesired behavior
quizquestion.explanation: You are performing initial steps of a behavior chain. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: You typically forget to bring your lunch with you to work. The night before you place a sticky note on the front door as a reminder. What type of self-management strategy are you using?
quizquestion.explanation: You are providing environmental prompts/cues. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Use token economies and other conditioned reinforcement systems

quizquestion.question: This is defined as a behavior change system that utilizes points or other tokens which are exchanged for backup reinforcers.
quizquestion.explanation: This is a token economy. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This is defined as items that are exchanged for using tokens.
quizquestion.explanation: This is a backup reinforcer. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This is a program in which the learners are moved up and down a hierarchy of privileges with regards to earning tokens.
quizquestion.explanation: This is a level system. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This is a program during which the learner is earns tokens contingent on appropriate behavior, but also loses tokens contingent on poor behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: This is a response cost. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: What type of consequence is a token in a token economy?
quizquestion.explanation: Tokens should function as generalized conditioned reinforcers. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is necessary in developing a token economy?
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above are necessary in developing a token economy. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is NOT necessary in developing a token economy?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Select maladaptive behaviors to decrease by removing tokens
quizquestion.explanation: Response cost programs are not necessary in token economies. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Initially, when implementing a token economy, the ratio between the number of tokens and the price of backup reinforcers should be:
quizquestion.explanation: The ratio should be low, so the learner is easily able to come into contact with reinforcement. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is NOT a challenge with implementing a token economy:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Behavior typically does not change significantly
wrongAnswer: It utilizes large amounts of time, energy, and resources.
May be cumbersome for behavior analyst and staff to implement
May be difficult to fade or remove.
quizquestion.explanation: Token economies are an effective procedure for changing behavior, even making significant changes. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: A response cost program is set up to function as:
quizquestion.explanation: Response cost programs are set up to function as negative punishment, by removing tokens contingent on maladaptive behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Use Direct Instruction

quizquestion.question: This type of teaching strategy uses scripted presentations in small groups. The instructor typically moves at a fast pace and relies heavily on active student responding (ASR).
quizquestion.explanation: Direct instruction uses scripted presentations in small groups. The instructor typically moves at a fast pace and relies heavily on active student responding (ASR). (Binder & Watkins, 2013)

quizquestion.question: Choral responding, in relation to direct instruction, involves:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: All students reciting the correct answer in unison
wrongAnswer: All students will sing the correct answer
One student will be asked to say the correct answer
Students will ask each other questions about the learning material.
quizquestion.explanation: Choral responding involves all students reciting the correct answer in unison. (Binder & Watkins, 2013)

quizquestion.question: What should the class size typically be while using direct instruction?
wrongAnswer: It doesn’t matter. Direct instruction works for all class sizes!
quizquestion.explanation: Small groups are best for direct instruction. (Binder & Watkins, 2013)

quizquestion.question: How should the learning material be presented during direct instruction?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: A written script is followed nearly exactly
wrongAnswer: A written script is used as a guide
The teacher is able to customize the content and script for the needs of the students
As long as the teacher covers the content, it doesn’t matter how exactly the content is taught
quizquestion.explanation: A written script is followed nearly exactly. (Binder & Watkins, 2013)

quizquestion.question: When errors are made by students during direct instruction, what does the teacher do?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Give immediate feedback as written in the script.
wrongAnswer: Give immediate feedback individualized to the need of the child.
The instructor moves on. This script doesn’t usually cover errors.
The teacher starts back at the beginning of the section to ensure all students achieve mastery.
quizquestion.explanation: Teachers are to give immediate feedback as written in the script. (Binder & Watkins, 2013)

quizquestion.question: These are devices used for individuals with severe speech deficits allowing them to communicate in other forms rather than vocal speech.
quizquestion.explanation: Augmentative communication systems are devices used for individuals with severe speech deficits allowing them to communicate in other forms rather than vocal speech. (Dattilo & Camarata, 1991)

quizquestion.question: What behavior-change system is used by establishing an appropriate communicative replacement behavior for a functionally equivalent problem behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Functional communication training is used by establishing an appropriate communicative replacement behavior for a functionally equivalent problem behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which teaching strategy uses naturally occurring interactions to teach skills in the natural environment?
quizquestion.explanation: Incidental teaching uses naturally occurring interactions to teach skills in the natural environment. (Hart & Risley, 1975)

quizquestion.question: Which teaching strategy is centered on the learner moving on in the curriculum at their own pace, as soon as they master the current content?
quizquestion.explanation: Personalized systems of instruction are centered on the learner moving on in the curriculum at their own pace, as soon as they master the current content. (Sherman, 1992)

quizquestion.question: This teaching strategy focuses on increasing fluency by using frequency as the primary measurement form.
quizquestion.explanation: Precision teaching focuses on increasing fluency by using frequency as the primary measurement form. (Binder & Watkins, 2013)

phase.name: Use precision teaching

quizquestion.question: This teaching strategy focuses on increasing fluency by using frequency as the primary measurement form.
quizquestion.explanation: Precision teaching focuses on increasing fluency by using frequency as the primary measurement form. (Binder & Watkins, 2013)

quizquestion.question: Which graphing tool is regularly used during precision teaching?
quizquestion.explanation: Standard celeration charts are usually used during precision teaching. (Binder & Watkins, 2013)

quizquestion.question: This occurs when the learner performs accurately and at a high rate of occurrence.
quizquestion.explanation: Fluency occurs when the learner performs accurately and at a high rate of occurrence. (Binder & Watkins, 2013)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is NOT an essential component of precision teaching
quizquestion.correctAnswer: The learner moves through the curriculum at their own pace
wrongAnswer: Focus on clearly defined and observable behavior
quizquestion.explanation: The learner does not move through the curriculum at their own pace.  That is true for personalized system of instruction. (Binder & Watkins, 2013)

quizquestion.question: To measure fluency, what two measurements are used?
quizquestion.explanation: Accuracy and frequency are used to measure fluency. (Binder & Watkins, 2013)

quizquestion.question: These are devices used for individuals with severe speech deficits allowing them to communicate in other forms rather than vocal speech.
quizquestion.explanation: Augmentative communication systems are devices used for individuals with severe speech deficits allowing them to communicate in other forms rather than vocal speech. (Dattilo & Camarata, 1991)

quizquestion.question: What behavior-change system is used by establishing an appropriate communicative replacement behavior for a functionally equivalent problem behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Functional communication training is used by establishing an appropriate communicative replacement behavior for a functionally equivalent problem behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which teaching strategy uses naturally occurring interactions to teach skills in the natural environment?
quizquestion.explanation: Incidental teaching uses naturally occurring interactions to teach skills in the natural environment. (Hart & Risley, 1975)

quizquestion.question: Which teaching strategy is centered on the learner moving on in the curriculum at their own pace, as soon as they master the current content?
quizquestion.explanation: Personalized systems of instruction are centered on the learner moving on in the curriculum at their own pace, as soon as they master the current content. (Sherman, 1992)

quizquestion.question: This type of teaching strategy uses scripted presentations in small groups. The instructor typically moves at a fast pace and relies heavily on active student responding (ASR).
quizquestion.explanation: Direct instruction uses scripted presentations in small groups. The instructor typically moves at a fast pace and relies heavily on active student responding (ASR). (Binder & Watkins, 2013)

phase.name: Use personalized systems of instruction (PSI)

quizquestion.question: Which teaching strategy is centered on the learner moving on in the curriculum at their own pace, as soon as they master the current content?
quizquestion.explanation: Personalized systems of instruction are centered on the learner moving on in the curriculum at their own pace, as soon as they master the current content. (Sherman, 1992)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is an essential component of PSI?
quizquestion.explanation: All of the answers above are correct. (Sherman, 1992)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is an essential component of PSI?
wrongAnswer: The teacher follows a written script
quizquestion.explanation: Frequent testing and immediate feedback are essential components of PSI. (Sherman, 1992)

quizquestion.question: Steven is using PSI to learn biology in an online class. He goes through the first short unit, but didn’t score the level needed on the first test for mastery. If this is truly a PSI program, what should occur next?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Steven is given immediate feedback on the questions he missed.
wrongAnswer: Steven may move on to the next unit
Steven will receive a penalty for errors on the test
Steven may retake the test once
quizquestion.explanation: Immediate feedback should be given, and Steven must remain on the same unit until mastery is achieved. (Sherman, 1992)

quizquestion.question: Steven is using PSI to learn biology in an online class. He goes through the first short unit and scored the level needed on the first test for mastery. If this is truly a PSI program, what should occur next?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Steven may move on to the next unit.
wrongAnswer: Steven will receive a penalty for errors on the test.
Steven may retake the test once.
Steven is given immediate feedback on the questions he missed.
quizquestion.explanation: Steven may move on to the next unit as soon as mastery is demonstrated for that unit. (Sherman, 1992)

quizquestion.question: These are devices used for individuals with severe speech deficits allowing them to communicate in other forms rather than vocal speech.
quizquestion.explanation: Augmentative communication systems are devices used for individuals with severe speech deficits allowing them to communicate in other forms rather than vocal speech. (Dattilo & Camarata, 1991)

quizquestion.question: What behavior-change system is used by establishing an appropriate communicative replacement behavior for a functionally equivalent problem behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Functional communication training is used by establishing an appropriate communicative replacement behavior for a functionally equivalent problem behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which teaching strategy uses naturally occurring interactions to teach skills in the natural environment?
quizquestion.explanation: Incidental teaching uses naturally occurring interactions to teach skills in the natural environment. (Hart & Risley, 1975)

quizquestion.question: This teaching strategy focuses on increasing fluency by using frequency as the primary measurement form.
quizquestion.explanation: Precision teaching focuses on increasing fluency by using frequency as the primary measurement form. (Binder & Watkins, 2013)

quizquestion.question: This type of teaching strategy uses scripted presentations in small groups. The instructor typically moves at a fast pace and relies heavily on active student responding (ASR).
quizquestion.explanation: Direct instruction uses scripted presentations in small groups. The instructor typically moves at a fast pace and relies heavily on active student responding (ASR). (Binder & Watkins, 2013)

phase.name: Use incidental teaching

quizquestion.question: Which teaching strategy uses naturally occurring interactions to teach skills in the natural environment?
quizquestion.explanation: Incidental teaching uses naturally occurring interactions to teach skills in the natural environment. (Hart & Risley, 1975)

quizquestion.question: Who can implement incidental teaching effectively?
quizquestion.explanation: One of the advantages of incidental teaching is that most people can be trained to conduct this effectively. (Hart & Risley, 1975)

quizquestion.question: How might you prepare the environment for incidental teaching with your child? You are hoping to begin to teach him how to ask for cookies appropriately.
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Place the cookies in sight but out of reach
wrongAnswer: Place the cookies out of sight and out of reach
Give the cookie to the child
quizquestion.explanation: When starting out, it would be best for the cookies to be in sight but out of reach. (Hart & Risley, 1975)

quizquestion.question: How might you prepare the environment for incidental teaching with your child? You are going to teach him how to ask for cookies appropriately.
wrongAnswer: Place the cookies in sight but out of reach
Put the cookie in sight when the child hasn’t eaten in a while
Bake cookies so the house smells like freshly baked cookies
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above would be good to prepare for incidental teaching. (Hart & Risley, 1975)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is an essential component of incidental teaching?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Occurs in the natural environment where the behavior is likely to occur
wrongAnswer: The learner moves through the curriculum at their own pace
The teacher must follow a script
quizquestion.explanation: Incidental teaching occurs in the natural environment where the behavior is likely to occur. (Hart & Risley, 1975)

quizquestion.question: These are devices used for individuals with severe speech deficits allowing them to communicate in other forms rather than vocal speech.
quizquestion.explanation: Augmentative communication systems are devices used for individuals with severe speech deficits allowing them to communicate in other forms rather than vocal speech. (Dattilo & Camarata, 1991)

quizquestion.question: What behavior-change system is used by establishing an appropriate communicative replacement behavior for a functionally equivalent problem behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Functional communication training is used by establishing an appropriate communicative replacement behavior for a functionally equivalent problem behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which teaching strategy is centered on the learner moving on in the curriculum at their own pace, as soon as they master the current content?
quizquestion.explanation: Personalized systems of instruction are centered on the learner moving on in the curriculum at their own pace, as soon as they master the current content. (Sherman, 1992)

quizquestion.question: This teaching strategy focuses on increasing fluency by using frequency as the primary measurement form.
quizquestion.explanation: Precision teaching focuses on increasing fluency by using frequency as the primary measurement form. (Binder & Watkins, 2013)

quizquestion.question: This type of teaching strategy uses scripted presentations in small groups. The instructor typically moves at a fast pace and relies heavily on active student responding (ASR).
quizquestion.explanation: Direct instruction uses scripted presentations in small groups. The instructor typically moves at a fast pace and relies heavily on active student responding (ASR). (Binder & Watkins, 2013)

phase.name: Use functional communication training

quizquestion.question: What behavior-change system is used by establishing an appropriate communicative replacement behavior for a functionally equivalent problem behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Functional communication training is used by establishing an appropriate communicative replacement behavior for a functionally equivalent problem behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: What is the purpose of functional communication training
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Teach an appropriate replacement behavior & reduce problem behavior
quizquestion.explanation: Functional communication training is intended to teach an appropriate replacement behavior & reduce problem behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: What differential reinforcement procedure is used during functional communication training?
quizquestion.explanation: Differential Reinforcement of Alternative behaviors is used as reinforcement is provided for appropriate responses and withheld for problem behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Before using functional communication training to decrease a problem behavior, what must occur?
wrongAnswer: You must conduct a functional assessment on the problem behavior
You must select a functionally equivalent communicative response
You must have the specific reinforcement ready to be delivered
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above must occur before using FCT to decrease problem behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Should prompts be used during functional communication training?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Yes, but they should be faded as soon as possible
wrongAnswer: Yes, prompts are naturally occurring in most environments
No, pure shaping is sufficient to teach an appropriate replacement behavior
No, prompting will lead to the learner becoming prompt dependent
quizquestion.explanation: Prompts may be used during functional communication training, but they should be faded as soon as possible. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: These are devices used for individuals with severe speech deficits allowing them to communicate in other forms rather than vocal speech.
quizquestion.explanation: Augmentative communication systems are devices used for individuals with severe speech deficits allowing them to communicate in other forms rather than vocal speech. (Dattilo & Camarata, 1991)

quizquestion.question: Which teaching strategy uses naturally occurring interactions to teach skills in the natural environment?
quizquestion.explanation: Incidental teaching uses naturally occurring interactions to teach skills in the natural environment. (Hart & Risley, 1975)

quizquestion.question: Which teaching strategy is centered on the learner moving on in the curriculum at their own pace, as soon as they master the current content?
quizquestion.explanation: Personalized systems of instruction are centered on the learner moving on in the curriculum at their own pace, as soon as they master the current content. (Sherman, 1992)

quizquestion.question: This teaching strategy focuses on increasing fluency by using frequency as the primary measurement form.
quizquestion.explanation: Precision teaching focuses on increasing fluency by using frequency as the primary measurement form. (Binder & Watkins, 2013)

quizquestion.question: This type of teaching strategy uses scripted presentations in small groups. The instructor typically moves at a fast pace and relies heavily on active student responding (ASR).
quizquestion.explanation: Direct instruction uses scripted presentations in small groups. The instructor typically moves at a fast pace and relies heavily on active student responding (ASR). (Binder & Watkins, 2013)

phase.name: Use augmentative communication systems

quizquestion.question: These are devices used for individuals with severe speech deficits allowing them to communicate in other forms rather than vocal speech.
quizquestion.explanation: Augmentative communication systems are devices used for individuals with severe speech deficits allowing them to communicate in other forms rather than vocal speech. (Dattilo & Camarata, 1991)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is an example of an augmentative communication system?
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above are examples of augmentative communication systems. (Dattilo & Camarata, 1991)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is an example of an augmentative communication system?
quizquestion.explanation: The tablet is an example of an augmentative communication system. (Dattilo & Camarata, 1991)

quizquestion.question: Why is vocal speech preferred to the use of augmentative communication systems?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Vocal speech is more widely understood by more audiences and is more transportable.
wrongAnswer: Vocal speech is NOT more preferred to the use of augmentative communication systems
Vocal speech is required to access most reinforcement
Vocal speech is easier to learn
quizquestion.explanation: Vocal speech is more widely understood by more audiences and is more easily transportable. Many augmentative communication systems can be heavy and difficult to carry with the speaker. (Dattilo & Camarata, 1991)

quizquestion.question: Communicating with an augmentative communication system is considered:
wrongAnswer: All of the above are accepted terms
quizquestion.explanation: Verbal behavior includes all forms of communication including speech, sign and the use of augmentative communication systems. (Dattilo & Camarata, 1991)

quizquestion.question: What behavior-change system is used by establishing an appropriate communicative replacement behavior for a functionally equivalent problem behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Functional communication training is used by establishing an appropriate communicative replacement behavior for a functionally equivalent problem behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which teaching strategy uses naturally occurring interactions to teach skills in the natural environment?
quizquestion.explanation: Incidental teaching uses naturally occurring interactions to teach skills in the natural environment. (Hart & Risley, 1975)

quizquestion.question: Which teaching strategy is centered on the learner moving on in the curriculum at their own pace, as soon as they master the current content?
quizquestion.explanation: Personalized systems of instruction are centered on the learner moving on in the curriculum at their own pace, as soon as they master the current content. (Sherman, 1992)

quizquestion.question: This teaching strategy focuses on increasing fluency by using frequency as the primary measurement form.
quizquestion.explanation: Precision teaching focuses on increasing fluency by using frequency as the primary measurement form. (Binder & Watkins, 2013)

quizquestion.question: This type of teaching strategy uses scripted presentations in small groups. The instructor typically moves at a fast pace and relies heavily on active student responding (ASR).
quizquestion.explanation: Direct instruction uses scripted presentations in small groups. The instructor typically moves at a fast pace and relies heavily on active student responding (ASR). (Binder & Watkins, 2013)

phase.name: Review records and available data at the outset of the case

quizquestion.question: According to the BACB’s ethical code, how long are behavior analysts to keep records?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: 7 years (and as otherwise required by law)
wrongAnswer: 2 years (and as otherwise required by law)
5 years (and as otherwise required by law)
quizquestion.explanation: The BACB requires that records be stored for at least 7 years and as otherwise required by law. This is according to the BACB “Professional and Ethical Compliance Code for Behavior Analyst” section 2.11.

quizquestion.question: Prior to taking on new clients, what factor(s) must be considered?
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above must be considered, according to the BACB “Professional and Ethical Compliance Code for Behavior Analyst” section 2.01.

quizquestion.question: Prior to taking on new clients, what factor(s) must be considered?
quizquestion.explanation: According to the BACB “Professional and Ethical Compliance Code for Behavior Analyst” section 2.01, organizational policies is consideration that needs to be made prior to accepting a client.

quizquestion.question: You have accepted to work with a new client. When considering which behaviors to address, you should:
quizquestion.explanation: The BACB task list identifies all of the above as things necessary in selecting problem behaviors.

quizquestion.question: You have accepted to work with a new client. When considering which behaviors to address, you should:
wrongAnswer: Receive an initial down payment for services
quizquestion.explanation: The BACB task list identifies that you should review records and available data.

quizquestion.question: When a case is transferred to a new behavior analyst, what is required to share confidential information such as past records and data?
wrongAnswer: Transferring a case is justification alone to release confidential records.
The behavior analyst needs to inform the client that they shared confidential information.
quizquestion.explanation: Consent of the client is needed to share confidential information, unless there is other legal reasons to do so as outlined in the BACB ethics code 2.08.

quizquestion.question: At what point should client’s data and records initially be reviewed?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: At the outset of the case
wrongAnswer: After the problem behavior has been accepted
quizquestion.explanation: Data and records are to be reviewed initially at the outset of the case according to the BACB task list G-01.

quizquestion.question: Who is defined as a client?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Whoever benefits from the behavior analytic services provided
quizquestion.explanation: The client is whoever benefits from the behavior analytic services according to the BACB ethics code 2.0.

quizquestion.question: Which of the following may be identified as a “client”?
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above may be identified as a client according to the BACB ethics code 2.0.

quizquestion.question: You just accepted Peter as a new client. He received services with another provider before coming on to your caseload. What should you request from the past provider?
wrongAnswer: 8 hours of in person training on the previous behavior plan
quizquestion.explanation: Past data and records should be requested.

phase.name: Consider biological/medical variables that may be affecting the client

quizquestion.question: For the past two days your client spits out his food. He doesn’t even eat typically preferred foods. What should be your course of action?
wrongAnswer: Reprimand every occurrence of spitting out food
quizquestion.explanation: Behavior analysts recommend a medical consultation when the behavior has potential of being medically related.

quizquestion.question: For the past two days your client spits out his food. He doesn’t even eat typically preferred foods. He was taken in to several physicians who all say that the behavior doesn’t appear to be medically related. What might be your next course of action?
wrongAnswer: Reprimand every occurrence of spitting out food
quizquestion.explanation: Behavior analysts recommend a medical consultation when the behavior has potential of being medically related.

quizquestion.question: You notice a drastic spike in the frequency of your client engaging in head hitting. There appears to be no recent major changes to his environment or supports. What should be your initial course of action?
wrongAnswer: Reprimand every occurrence of hitting his head-
quizquestion.explanation: Behavior analysts recommend a medical consultation when the behavior has potential of being medically related.

quizquestion.question: You notice a drastic spike in the frequency of your client engaging in head hitting. There appears to be no recent major changes to his environment or supports. After seeking a medical consult, there appears to be no medical or biological factors. What should be your next course of action?
wrongAnswer: Reprimand every occurrence of hitting his head-
quizquestion.explanation: Behavior analysts recommend a medical consultation when the behavior has potential of being medically related.

quizquestion.question: You notice a drastic spike in the frequency of your client engaging in head hitting. His physician states that this behavior appears to be headache related and prescribes pain killers. What should be your next course of action?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Wait for the behavior to be medically addressed, and seek out further medical consult if the behavior continues.
wrongAnswer: Reprimand every occurrence of hitting his head-
quizquestion.explanation: Behavior analysts recommend a medical consultation when the behavior has potential of being medically related.

quizquestion.question: Your client engages in frequent urinary incontinence. You have been working with her for 2 years, and this has never been an issue before. What may be your course of action?
wrongAnswer: Ignore the behavior and teach her how to appropriately seek attention
Continue prompting task completion and teach how to appropriately get out of a task
quizquestion.explanation: Behavior analysts recommend a medical consultation when the behavior has potential of being medically related.

quizquestion.question: Your client engages in frequent urinary incontinence. You have been working with her for 2 years, and this has never been an issue before. Her medical doctors state that there is no apparent medical component to this behavior. What may be your next course of action?
wrongAnswer: Ignore the behavior and teach her how to appropriately seek attention
Continue prompting task completion and teach how to appropriately get out of a task
quizquestion.explanation: Behavior analysts recommend a medical consultation when the behavior has potential of being medically related.

quizquestion.question: Your client engages in frequent urinary incontinence. You have been working with her for 2 years, and this has never been an issue before. Her medical doctors state that there is no apparent medical component to this behavior. You complete a functional assessment and the behavior appears to be escape maintained. What may be your next course of action?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Continue prompting task completion and teach how to appropriately get out of a task
wrongAnswer: Ignore the behavior and teach her how to appropriately seek attention
quizquestion.explanation: Escape extinction and teaching a functionally equivalent replacement behavior are functionally based interventions.

quizquestion.question: Your client engages in frequent urinary incontinence. You have been working with her for 2 years, and this has never been an issue before. Her medical doctors state that there appears to be a medical component and prescribes a medication to address a urinary tract infection. What may be your next course of action?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Wait for this to be medically addressed and recommend further medical consultation if the behavior continues.
wrongAnswer: Ignore the behavior and teach her how to appropriately seek attention
Continue prompting task completion and teach how to appropriately get out of a task
quizquestion.explanation: Behavior analysts recommend a medical consultation when the behavior has potential of being medically related.

quizquestion.question: Who is defined as a client?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Whoever benefits from the behavior analytic services provided
quizquestion.explanation: The client is whoever benefits from the behavior analytic services according to the BACB ethics code 2.0.

phase.name: Conduct a preliminary assessment of the client in order to identify the referral problem.

quizquestion.question: What involves a variety of methods including direct observations and other indirect measures to inform behavior change programs?
quizquestion.explanation: Behavioral assessments involve a variety of methods including direct observations and other indirect measures to inform behavior change programs. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: You are opening your own company and are looking for appropriate ways to gain clients. Which of the following is an appropriate method?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Create a website with explanations of ABA strategies you use.
wrongAnswer: Provide a small financial incentive for referrals
Ask past clients to supply testimonials to post on your website
quizquestion.explanation: Behavior analysts may not use incentives for referrals or use testimonials. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is a form of indirect assessments?
quizquestion.explanation: Indirect assessments are those which use data derived from recollections, or subjective ratings of events. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is a form of indirect assessments?
quizquestion.explanation: Indirect assessments are those which use data derived from recollections, or subjective ratings of events. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is a form of direct assessments?
quizquestion.explanation: Direct assessments are those which use information about the individual as it occurs. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is a form of direct assessments?
quizquestion.explanation: Direct assessments are those which use information about the individual as it occurs. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which assessments use information about the individual by observing the individual as the behavior occurs?
quizquestion.explanation: Direct assessments are those which use information about the individual as it occurs. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which assessments use data derived from recollections, or subjective ratings of events?
quizquestion.explanation: Indirect assessments are those which use data derived from recollections, or subjective ratings of events. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: What is a purpose of conducting a preliminary assessment?
wrongAnswer: Consider potential interventions to be used
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above are purposes of conducting preliminary assessment. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is an assessment/test that a BCBA may conduct?
quizquestion.explanation: BCBA’s are not trained to conduct IQ tests, competency evaluations, or diagnose Autism. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Explain behavioral concepts using nontechnical language

quizquestion.question: When speaking to clients, parents, and other individuals in the community about behavior analysis, how should we explain behavioral principles?
wrongAnswer: Use technical language first, then explain it using easy to understand language, in an effort to teach them the technical language
quizquestion.explanation: It is not our job to teach the difficult vocabulary behavior analysts use. Using every day language will be best practice to explain interventions to other people.

quizquestion.question: How might you explain “consequences” to somebody who does not understand ABA jargon?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Something good or bad that happens after a person does something
wrongAnswer: Imposing a fine for doing something unacceptable
A stimulus change that follows a behavior of interest
Providing rewards, attention, praise, etc. to get more of the behavior
quizquestion.explanation: It is not our job to teach the difficult vocabulary behavior analysts use. Using every day language will be best practice to explain interventions to other people.

quizquestion.question: How might you explain “consequences” to somebody who understands ABA jargon well?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: A stimulus change that follows a behavior of interest
wrongAnswer: Something good or bad that happens after a person does something
Imposing a fine for doing something unacceptable
Providing rewards, attention, praise, etc. to get more of the behavior
quizquestion.explanation: It is not our job to teach the difficult vocabulary behavior analysts use. Using every day language will be best practice to explain interventions to other people.

quizquestion.question: How might you explain positive reinforcement to somebody who does not understand ABA jargon?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Providing rewards, attention, praise, etc. to get more of the behavior
wrongAnswer: Occurs when a behavior is followed immediately by the presentation of a stimulus that decreases the future frequency of the behavior.
Something good or bad that happens after a person does something
Imposing a fine for doing something unacceptable
quizquestion.explanation: It is not our job to teach the difficult vocabulary behavior analysts use. Using every day language will be best practice to explain interventions to other people.

quizquestion.question: How might you explain positive reinforcement to somebody who understands ABA jargon well?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Occurs when a behavior is followed immediately by the presentation of a stimulus that decreases the future frequency of the behavior.
wrongAnswer: Providing rewards, attention, praise, etc. to get more of the behavior
Something good or bad that happens after a person does something
Imposing a fine for doing something unacceptable
quizquestion.explanation: It is not our job to teach the difficult vocabulary behavior analysts use. Using every day language will be best practice to explain interventions to other people. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: How might you explain the term “stimulus generalization” to somebody who does not understand ABA jargon?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Being able to apply something learned in class in a different setting
wrongAnswer: When an antecedent stimulus has a history of evoking a response that has been reinforced in its presence, the same type of behavior tends to be evoked by stimuli that share similar physical properties with the controlling antecedent stimulus
Something good or bad that happens after a person does something
Imposing a fine for doing something unacceptable
quizquestion.explanation: It is not our job to teach the difficult vocabulary behavior analysts use. Using every day language will be best practice to explain interventions to other people. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: How might you explain the term “stimulus generalization” to somebody who understands ABA jargon well?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: When an antecedent stimulus has a history of evoking a response that has been reinforced in its presence, the same type of behavior tends to be evoked by stimuli that share similar physical properties with the controlling antecedent stimulus
wrongAnswer: Something good or bad that happens after a person does something
Imposing a fine for doing something unacceptable
Being able to apply something learned in class in a different setting
quizquestion.explanation: It is not our job to teach the difficult vocabulary behavior analysts use. Using every day language will be best practice to explain interventions to other people. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: How might you explain the term “negative reinforcement” to somebody who does not understand ABA jargon?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Behaving in a way to avoid something unpleasant, like a reprimand.
wrongAnswer: Providing rewards, attention, praise, etc. to get more of the behavior
Being able to apply something learned in class in a different setting
The removal of a stimulus following a response, which increases the future frequency of that response
quizquestion.explanation: It is not our job to teach the difficult vocabulary behavior analysts use. Using every day language will be best practice to explain interventions to other people. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: How might you explain the term “negative reinforcement” to somebody who understands ABA jargon well?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: The removal of a stimulus following a response, which increases the future frequency of that response
wrongAnswer: Behaving in a way to avoid something unpleasant, like a reprimand.
Providing rewards, attention, praise, etc. to get more of the behavior
Being able to apply something learned in class in a different setting
quizquestion.explanation: It is not our job to teach the difficult vocabulary behavior analysts use. Using every day language will be best practice to explain interventions to other people. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: How might you explain the term “extinction” to somebody who does not understand ABA jargon?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Reducing behavior by withholding the item or attention the person wants
wrongAnswer: Providing rewards, attention, praise, etc. to get more of the behavior
Being able to apply something learned in class in a different setting
The discontinuing of a reinforcement of a previously reinforced behavior
quizquestion.explanation: It is not our job to teach the difficult vocabulary behavior analysts use. Using every day language will be best practice to explain interventions to other people. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Describe and explain behavior, including private events, in behavior-analytic (non-mentalistic) terms

quizquestion.question: What is defined as “A fictitious or hypothetical variable that often takes the form of another name for the observed phenomenon it claims to explain and contributes nothing to a functional account of the phenomenon?
quizquestion.explanation: This is the definition of an explanatory fiction. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This is an approach to explaining behavior that assumes a mental (or inner) dimension exists that differs from a behavioral dimension.
quizquestion.explanation: This is the definition of mentalism. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This occurs when explaining behavior, when the description of the behavior is the same as the cause of the behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: Circular reasoning occurs when the description of the behavior is the same as the cause of the behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This occurs when the behavior is accessible only to the person engaging in the behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: Private events occur when the behavior is accessible only to the person engaging in the behavior. (Tourinho, 2006)

quizquestion.question: Jordan closes his eyes and “thinks” about a blue ball. Thinking about the blue ball is an example of a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: Private events occur when the behavior is accessible only to the person engaging in the behavior. (Tourinho, 2006)

quizquestion.question: Jordan closes his eyes and “thinks” about a blue ball. Closing his eyes is an example of a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: Private events occur when the behavior is accessible only to the person engaging in the behavior. (Tourinho, 2006)

quizquestion.question: Sally goes into the bathroom by herself and urinates. Nobody is in the bathroom with her, and nobody can see Sally. Urinating in the bathroom is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Private events occur when the behavior is accessible only to the person engaging in the behavior. Although Sally was alone in the bathroom, had somebody been present, urinating would be measurable. (Tourinho, 2006)

quizquestion.question: Sally’s heart is beating. Nobody is feeling her heartbeat. Sally’s heart beating is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Private events occur when the behavior is accessible only to the person engaging in the behavior. Although nobody is listening to her heart beating, somebody COULD listen to her heart beat. (Tourinho, 2006)

quizquestion.question: Jordan recites the alphabet in his head. This thinking behavior is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Private events occur when the behavior is accessible only to the person engaging in the behavior. (Tourinho, 2006)

quizquestion.question: Molly goes in to her room all by herself and hits her head. Hitting her head is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Private events occur when the behavior is accessible only to the person engaging in the behavior. Although Molly was alone in her room, had somebody been present the COULD have seen the behavior. (Tourinho, 2006)

phase.name: Provide behavior-analytic services in collaboration with others who support and/or provide services to one’s clients.

quizquestion.question: Who is defined as a client?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Whoever benefits from the behavior analytic services provided
quizquestion.explanation: The client is whoever benefits from the behavior analytic services according to the BACB ethics code 2.0.

quizquestion.question: Which of the following may be identified as a “client”?
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above may be identified as a client according to the BACB ethics code 2.0.

quizquestion.question: This occurs when a principal party has a vested interest in the outcome of the interaction.
quizquestion.explanation: This is a conflict of interest

quizquestion.question: During a team meeting for your client, one team member is adamant about starting a treatment that is not evidence based. What is should you do?
wrongAnswer: Ask the team to take data on the effects of the treatment. If no improvement is seen, then it should be terminated.
As the BCBA, you should not implement the treatment
Ask the team member if they have any research they could provide on the effects of the treatment.
quizquestion.explanation: All of the answers above would be appropriate.

quizquestion.question: During a team meeting for your client, one team member is adamant about starting a treatment that is not evidence based. What is should you do?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Ask the team to take data on the effects of the treatment. If no improvement is seen, then it should be terminated.
wrongAnswer: Tell the team that you will not be part of a team that uses non-evidence based treatments
Implement your own treatment to counteract anything that the rest of the team does.
quizquestion.explanation: It would be appropriate to ask the team to take data on the effects of the treatment. If no improvement is seen, then it should be terminated.

quizquestion.question: Lou is a BCBA who frequently demeans those working under him. What ethical concern is this an example of?
quizquestion.explanation: This is a concern with his professional relationships.

quizquestion.question: Lou is a BCBA and his client recently gave him a gift card as a thank you for his hard work. What ethical concern is this an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: BCBA’s should not receive gifts. This creates a potential conflict of interest.

quizquestion.question: Lou is an ABA professor. He requires his students to promote his twitter account as part of their grade. This is an example of what ethical concern?
quizquestion.explanation: This is an example of an exploitative relationship.

quizquestion.question: Lou serves in his local church teaching religion classes. He is also a BCBA. He recently started providing ABA therapy with one of his students at church. This is an example of what ethical concern?
quizquestion.explanation: This is an example of multiple relationships.

quizquestion.question: While providing ABA services to a young lady, Lou has begun dating her. This is an example of what ethical concern?
quizquestion.explanation: This is an example of multiple relationships.

phase.name: Practice within one’s limits of professional competence in applied behavior analysis, and obtain consultation, supervision, and training, or make referrals as necessary

quizquestion.question: You are opening your own company and are looking for appropriate ways to gain clients. Which of the following is an appropriate method?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Create a website with explanations of ABA strategies you use.
wrongAnswer: Provide a small financial incentive for referrals
Ask past clients to supply testimonials to post on your website
quizquestion.explanation: Behavior analysts may not use incentives for referrals or use testimonials. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This is given by the BACB stating you are competent to practice as a behavior analyst.
quizquestion.explanation: Certification is given by the BACB stating you are competent to practice as a behavior analyst. This process does not involve the law from where you reside.

quizquestion.question: This is given by the local government usually involving the BACB as well. This restricts who can call themselves different titles and places legal parameters on how you can practice.
quizquestion.explanation: Licensure is given by the local government usually involving the BACB as well. This restricts who can call themselves different titles and places legal parameters on how you can practice.

quizquestion.question: Which of the following can the BACB do if the ethical standards are violated, or the individual is deemed not competent to practice as a behavior analyst?
quizquestion.explanation: The BACB may deny initial certification, revoke certification, or suspend certification

quizquestion.question: Which of the following can the BACB do if the ethical standards are violated, or the individual is deemed not competent to practice as a behavior analyst?
quizquestion.explanation: The BACB may deny initial certification, revoke certification, or suspend certification

quizquestion.question: What determines if a behavior analyst is competent to work with a specific client?
quizquestion.explanation: According to the ethical code 1.02 behavior analysts only practice within the boundaries of the competence defined as being commensurate with their education, training, and supervised experience.

quizquestion.question: Joseph wants to start practicing Organizational Behavior Management by consulting with companies in the private sector. He has read several books on the matter, but is lacking experience and training in OBM. What should Joseph do?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Seek out a mentor with more experience that may be able to supervise his work.
wrongAnswer: Learn as he goes. He may begin practicing and learn from his mistakes.
Do not practice OBM without experience.
Reading several books is sufficient to practice OBM effectively and ethically.
quizquestion.explanation: Seek out a mentor with more experience that may be able to supervise his work.

quizquestion.question: Phillip is recommended to implement a treatment that is lacking research. There is one article he found that has promising results. The strategy does not have a high risk of being harmful to his client. What should Phillip do?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Consider a more established treatment. If the situation is unique, and other treatments do not apply, it would be appropriate to conduct research and further the literature on the treatment.
wrongAnswer: Refer the client to another person with more experience
quizquestion.explanation: Behavior analysts rely on scientific knowledge and conduct research to further that knowledge.

quizquestion.question: How do behavior analysts maintain knowledge of current scientific information?
quizquestion.explanation: Behavior analysts do all of the above to maintain knowledge of current scientific information.

quizquestion.question: How do behavior analysts maintain knowledge of current scientific information?
quizquestion.explanation: Journal articles should be a source of knowledge for behavior analysts.

phase.name: Identify and make environmental changes that reduce the need for behavior analysis services

quizquestion.question: Mary is a BCBA serving several clients in her area. Due to a family emergency she needs to relocate to another state for several months. Mary should:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Not abandon the clients without ensuring the cases are transferred
wrongAnswer: Do what she needs to do in emergency situations
Inform the clients that she may be able to continue services in a few months when she returns.
Resolve the family situation first, and then decide later on what to do with the caseload.
quizquestion.explanation: Mary should do everything possible to ensure the cases are transferred to a qualified replacement.

quizquestion.question: When would be an appropriate time to discontinue services with a client?
wrongAnswer: The client requests discontinuation of services
Is not benefitting from the service
Is being harmed by the service
quizquestion.explanation: It would be appropriate to discontinue services for all of the reasons listed above.

quizquestion.question: When would be an appropriate time to discontinue services with a client?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: The client has met the measurable objectives laid out at the onset of services
wrongAnswer: The behavior analyst is sick, and will be unable to work for several days
The client has met one of the two measureable objectives laid out at the onset of services.
quizquestion.explanation: It would be appropriate to discontinue services if the client has met the measurable objectives laid out at the onset of services

quizquestion.question: You are hired to consult with a young boy who engages in frequent hitting. His mother wants you to help the boy learn not to hit. What might be the criterion you set to discontinue services?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: When the boy has gone 2 weeks without engaging in any hitting
wrongAnswer: When the boy has gone 12 months without engaging in any hitting
When the boy is no longer aggressive
With the boy has progressed to the point to where services are no longer needed.
quizquestion.explanation: There needs to be set criteria that includes a reasonable amount of time.

quizquestion.question: You are working with Ella who engages in frequent tantrums. You have worked with her for 12 months and have not seen any progress. You have changed the behavior intervention plan multiple times, but they haven’t seemed to help the behavior. What could you do?
wrongAnswer: Refer the client to another behavior analyst who may have more experience
Attend a conference or workshop addressing Ella’s specific needs
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above would be appropriate.

quizquestion.question: You are working with Ella who engages in frequent tantrums. You have worked with her for 12 months and have not seen any progress. You have changed the behavior intervention plan multiple times, but they haven’t seemed to help the behavior. What could you do?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Refer the client to another behavior analyst who may have more experience
wrongAnswer: Seek out a mental health diagnosis
quizquestion.explanation: Refer the client to someone who may have more experience with similar situations.

quizquestion.question: Joey is sleeping well and no longer engaging in angry outbursts. He has met the criteria established at the onset of services to discontinue services. As the behavior analyst, what do you do?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Terminate services by slowly fading all behavioral interventions you are providing
wrongAnswer: Immediately terminate services once the criteria are met
Look for more behaviors that would benefit from your services
Ask Joey if he wants you to leave or stay working with him
quizquestion.explanation: Terminate services once he has met the established criteria by slowly fading all behavioral interventions.

quizquestion.question: When billing for services you provide, what should you include in the billing reports?
wrongAnswer: State the nature of the services provided
State the identity of the provider
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above should be included.

quizquestion.question: When billing for services you provide, what should you include in the billing reports?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: State the nature of the services provided
wrongAnswer: A record of billing from the past 12 months
An increase in you fees each year
quizquestion.explanation: The billing report should state the nature of the services provided.

quizquestion.question: Adam is receiving behavior analysis services, but is unhappy with the service you provide. He asks for termination of services. What do you do?
wrongAnswer: Provide data to show the positive effect of your services
Provide a termination of services fee to deter him from terminating services
Provide a list of testimonials of satisfied consumers
quizquestion.explanation: It is appropriate to terminate services as requested by the client.

phase.name: Select a measurement system to obtain representative data given the dimensions of the behavior and the logistics of observing and recording

quizquestion.question: Frequency is:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: A simple count of the total occurrences of behavior
wrongAnswer: The number of occurrences of the behavior across time
The amount of time from the discriminative stimulus to the occurrence of the behavior
The amount of time between occurrences of behavior
quizquestion.explanation: Many refer to “Rate” as synonymous to Frequency, but according to the BACB Fourth Edition Task List, Frequency and Rate are separate measures. “Frequency” is synonymous with “Count”.

quizquestion.question: Select the word the means the same as “Count”
quizquestion.explanation: Frequency is defined as a simple count of the total occurrences of behavior, which is different from Rate, according to the BACB Fourth Edition Task List.

quizquestion.question: Frequency across time is referred to as
quizquestion.explanation: Rate is defined as the number of responses per unit of time. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: John is a BCBA wanting to measure how often George engages in tongue clicking. What would be an appropriate measure?
quizquestion.explanation: Rate is usually the best measure for free operant behaviors. .(Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Duration is based on which measurable dimension of behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Duration is based on the measureable dimension of behavior “Temporal Extent”. Temporal extent explains that every instance of behavior occurs during some amount of time. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Jeremy engages in on task behavior for extended periods of time. Which measure would be most beneficial to use to measure this behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Duration is usually the best measure for continuous behaviors. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Latency is defined as:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: The amount of time between the stimulus and the response
wrongAnswer: Amount of time in which a behavior occurs
The amount of time between two responses
quizquestion.explanation: Latency is defined as the amount of time between the stimulus and the response. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: After 3.5 seconds of prompting Mary, she finally got up and placed her dishes in the dishwasher, which took her 6 seconds to complete. In this scenario 3.5 seconds refers to:
quizquestion.explanation: Latency is defined as the amount of time between the stimulus and the response. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: What is the amount of time that occurs between two consecutive instances of a response?
quizquestion.explanation: IRT is defined as the amount of time that occurs between two consecutive instances of a response. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Calculate the percent of occurrence of completed tasks for John. He was prompted to complete 20 different tasks and refused only 3 times. He complied following all other prompts.
quizquestion.explanation: Percent of occurrence is defined as a ratio formed by combining the same dimensional quantities (i.e., Duration ÷ Duration). (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Select a schedule of observation and recording periods

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is a continuous measurement procedure?
quizquestion.explanation: Event recording and Timing are common procedures used when collecting continuous measurement data. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is a continuous measurement procedure?
quizquestion.explanation: Event recording and Timing are common procedures used when collecting continuous measurement data. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Wrist counters, hand-tally digital counters, tally marks, are all devices that can be used with which measurement procedure?
quizquestion.explanation: Wrist counters, digital counters, or simple tally marks on paper can all be used with event recording procedures. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Stopwatches/timers are necessary for which measurement procedure?
quizquestion.explanation: Timing measurement procedures require a device to track time for accurate time measures. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: During this discontinuous measurement procedure, the observer marks “no” if the behavior does not occur throughout the entire session.
quizquestion.explanation: Whole Interval Recording is when the observer marks “yes” when the behavior occurs during the entire session observed. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: During this discontinuous measurement procedure, the observer marks “no” if the behavior did not occur at all during the session. If there were any occurrences they mark “yes”.
quizquestion.explanation: Partial interval recording occurs when the observer marks “yes” when the behavior occurs at all during the entire session. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: During a 10 second interval, Ruby engages in disruptive behavior twice for 5 seconds total duration. Using a whole interval recording procedure, what would be marked on the data sheet?
quizquestion.explanation: Whole Interval Recording is when the observer marks “yes” when the behavior occurs during the entire session observed. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: During a 10 second interval, Ruby engages in disruptive behavior twice for 5 seconds total duration. Using a partial interval recording procedure, what would be marked on the data sheet?
quizquestion.explanation: Partial interval recording occurs when the observer marks “yes” when the behavior occurs at all during the entire session. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This is defined as the physical shape or form of a behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: Topography is defined as the physical shape or form of a behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This is defined as the force or intensity with which a response is emitted.
quizquestion.explanation: Magnitude is defined as the force or intensity with which a response is emitted. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Select a data display that effectively communicates relevant quantitative relations

quizquestion.question: What is the most commonly used graphic display used by behavior analysts?
quizquestion.explanation: Line graphs are most commonly used. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This type of graph allows for data to be displayed between two dimensions (e.g., frequency of behavior across time). Each data point is connect to the next with a line.
quizquestion.explanation: Line graphs allow for data to be displayed between two dimensions (e.g., frequency of behavior across time). Each data point is connect to the next with a line. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This graph is also referred to as a histogram
quizquestion.explanation: The bar graph is also called a histogram. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This type of graph allows you to display and compare discrete sets of data that are not related to one another by a common underlying dimension by which the horizontal axis can be scaled.
quizquestion.explanation: The bar graph allows you to display and compare discrete sets of data that are not related to one another by a common underlying dimension by which the horizontal axis can be scaled. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This type of graph was developed by Skinner to collect data in the experimental analysis of behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: The cumulative record was developed by Skinner. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This type of graph displays the total number of responses emitted during a single session of observation.
quizquestion.explanation: The cumulative record displays the total number of responses emitted during a single session of observation. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is a semilogarithmic chart?
quizquestion.explanation: The standard celeration chart is a semilogarithmic chart. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This type of graph is used to display behaviors that are accelerating or decelerating in rate. The vertical axis displays frequency at increasing and non-proportional increments.
quizquestion.explanation: The standard celeration chart is used to display behaviors that are accelerating or decelerating in rate. The vertical axis displays frequency at increasing and non-proportional increments. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This type of graph shows the relative distribution of individual measures in a data set with respect to the variables depicted by the x and y axes. Data points are unconnected.
quizquestion.explanation: The scatterplot shows the relative distribution of individual measures in a data set with respect to the variables depicted by the x and y axes. Data points are unconnected. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This type of graph allows you to discover the temporal distribution of a target behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: The scatterplot shows the relative distribution of individual measures in a data set with respect to the variables depicted by the x and y axes. Data points are unconnected. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Evaluate changes in level, trend, and variability

quizquestion.question: This is defined as the extent to which multiple measures of behavior yield different outcomes.
quizquestion.explanation: Variability is defined as the extent to which multiple measures of behavior yield different outcomes.

quizquestion.question: This is defined as the value on the vertical axis scale around which a set of behavioral measures converge.
quizquestion.explanation: Level is defined as the value on the vertical axis scale around which a set of behavioral measures converge.

quizquestion.question: This is defined as the overall direction taken by a data path.
quizquestion.explanation: Trend is defined as the overall direction taken by a data path.

quizquestion.question: Describe the Trend of the following line graph:
quizquestion.explanation: This graph appears to be decreasing.

quizquestion.question: Describe the variability of the following graph:
quizquestion.explanation: This graph appears to highly variable

quizquestion.question: Describe the trend of the following graph:
quizquestion.explanation: This graph appears to have zero trend.

quizquestion.question: Describe the variability of the following graph:
quizquestion.explanation: This graph appears to have low variability.

quizquestion.question: Describe the level of the following graph:
quizquestion.explanation: Level is only determinable if given the value of the data points, or in comparison to another line.

quizquestion.question: Describe the trend of the following graph:
quizquestion.explanation: This graph appears to be increasing.

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is the most accurate visual analysis of this graph?
quizquestion.explanation: This graph appears to be increasing and low variability.

phase.name: Evaluate temporal relations between observed variables

quizquestion.question: Rate is measured using which measurable dimension of behavior?
