quizquestion.explanation: Rate is based on the measurable dimension of behavior “Repeatability”. Repeatability states that instance of a response class can occur repeatedly through time. You can count behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: The measurable dimension of behavior “repeatability” can be defined as:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Instances of behavior can occur repeatedly through time
wrongAnswer: Every instance of behavior occurs at a certain point in time
Behavior always repeats if it has happened before
quizquestion.explanation: Rate is based on the measurable dimension of behavior “Repeatability”. Repeatability states that instance of a response class can occur repeatedly through time. You can count behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Duration is based on which measurable dimension of behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Duration is based on the measureable dimension of behavior “Temporal Extent”. Temporal extent explains that every instance of behavior occurs during some amount of time. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Temporal Extent is defined as:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Every instance of behavior occurs during some amount of time
wrongAnswer: Instances of behavior can occur repeatedly through time
Every instance of behavior occurs at a certain point in time
quizquestion.explanation: Duration is based on the measureable dimension of behavior “Temporal Extent”. Temporal extent explains that every instance of behavior occurs during some amount of time. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Define Temporal Locus
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Behavior occurs at a certain point in time with respect to other events.
wrongAnswer: Behavior occurs during some amount of time
Behavior always occurs after an antecedent.
quizquestion.explanation: Latency is based on the dimension “Temporal Locus” Temporal locus refers to that behavior occurs at a certain point in time with respect to other events. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Latency is based on which dimension of behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Latency is based on the dimension “Temporal Locus” Temporal locus refers to that behavior occurs at a certain point in time with respect to other events. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: IRT is based on which dimension of behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: IRT is based on the dimension ”temporal locus”. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which dimension of behavior is used when reporting a percentage?
quizquestion.explanation: Percentages use ratios of the same dimensional quantity. The dimensional quantity is canceled out in the ratio equation and no longer contains those dimensional quantities. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This type of graph shows the relative distribution of individual measures in a data set with respect to the variables depicted by the x and y axes. Data points are unconnected.
quizquestion.explanation: The scatterplot shows the relative distribution of individual measures in a data set with respect to the variables depicted by the x and y axes. Data points are unconnected. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This type of graph allows you to discover the temporal distribution of a target behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: The scatterplot shows the relative distribution of individual measures in a data set with respect to the variables depicted by the x and y axes. Data points are unconnected. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Define Behavior in observable and measurable terms

quizquestion.question: This type of behavioral definition identifies responses as members of the targeted response class solely by their common effect on the environment.
quizquestion.explanation: Function-based definitions identify responses as members of the targeted response class solely by their common effect on the environment. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This type of behavioral definition identifies responses by the shape or form of the behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: Topography based definitions identify responses by the shape or form of the behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is the best example of an observable and measurable behavioral definition?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Hitting any person with an open hand or closed fist
quizquestion.explanation: “hitting any person with an open hand or closed fist” is the best example of an observable and measurable behavioral definition. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is the best example of an observable and measurable behavioral definition?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Any occurrence of making self-disparaging remarks or threats of harming himself.
wrongAnswer: Showing depressive symptoms congruent with a diagnosis of major depressive disorder
Showing signs of depression or other emotional instability
quizquestion.explanation: “Any occurrence of making self-disparaging remarks or threats of harming himself” is the best answer. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following will strengthen a behavioral definition?
wrongAnswer: Data collection guidelines such as an onset and offset of the behavior
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above would be correct. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: You are working with a client, trying to increase the occurrences of appropriate requests when they ask for an item. What might be the behavioral definition for this behavior?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Defined as Mary naming the item she wants as well as saying “please”.
wrongAnswer: Defined as Mary having proper manners when requesting an item.
Defined as Mary being polite when wanting an item.
Defined as Mary showing manners by asking nicely for items with which she wants.
quizquestion.explanation: Mary naming the item she wants as well as saying “please” is the most observable and measurable definition provided. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: What is a purpose of writing observable and measurable behavioral definitions?
wrongAnswer: To ensure inter-observer agreement is high with data collection
To encompass the entire behavior of concern
To ensure that contingencies are delivered at appropriate times (when contingent on said behavior)
quizquestion.explanation: All of the answers above are correct. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: What is a purpose of writing observable and measurable behavioral definitions?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: To ensure inter-observer agreement is high with data collection
wrongAnswer: To help create standardized behavioral definitions across the field of ABA.
quizquestion.explanation: One purpose of writing observable and measureable behavioral definitions is that it helps to ensure inter-observer agreement is high with data collection. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Behavioral definitions should be:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Individualized so the definition encompasses all relevant behaviors of concern
wrongAnswer: Standardized to increase the likelihood of exact replications in research
Fluid, meaning open to interpretation for data collectors.
Concise, even if that means leaving out relevant responses often of concern.
quizquestion.explanation: Behavioral definitions should be individualized so the definition encompasses all relevant behaviors of concern. Although concise definitions are easier to understand, it is best for them to be concise, yet contain all relevant responses often of concern. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question:
Tray engages in encopresis, where he will defecate all around his house. What is missing from the following behavioral definition?
“Defined as Tray defecating anywhere other than the toilet. Frequency of this behavior will be tracked by marking a tally after every occurrence of Tray engaging in the behavior.”
wrongAnswer: There needs to be a more observable definition
The definition needs to be more individualized to Tray’s circumstances.
quizquestion.explanation: Examples and non-examples may improve this behavioral definition. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Define environmental variables in observable and measurable terms

quizquestion.question: Which conditioned motivating operation is created by being paired with an unconditioned motivating operation, gaining the same behavior-altering effects as that UMO?
quizquestion.explanation: Surrogate CMO’s are created by being paired with an unconditioned motivating operation, gaining the same behavior-altering effects as that UMO. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: How can you weaken the effects of surrogate CMOs?
wrongAnswer: Weaken the MO related to the end of the behavior sequence
quizquestion.explanation: Unpairing will weaken the effects of a surrogate CMO. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which conditioned motivating operation precedes the onset of painful stimulation and functions as a warning stimulus?
quizquestion.explanation: Reflexive CMOs precede the onset of painful stimulation and functions as a warning stimulus. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: How can you weaken the effects of a Reflexive CMO?
wrongAnswer: Weaken the MO related to the end of the behavior sequence
quizquestion.explanation: Extinction and unpairing will weaken the effects of a CMO-R. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which conditioned motivating operation involves UMOs functioning as both a UMO and a CMO for consecutive contingencies?
quizquestion.explanation: Transitive CMOs involve UMOs functioning as both a UMO and a CMO for consecutive contingencies. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: How can you weaken the effects of a transitive CMO?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Weaken the MO related to the end of the behavior sequence
quizquestion.explanation: CMO-Ts are weakened by weakening the MO related to the end of the behavior sequence. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Philip was diagnosed with anxiety. He frequently engages in finger rubbing to the point for causing blisters on his thumb and index finger. After conducting a functional assessment, it was determined that finger rubbing typically results in Phillip receiving hugs from his family in an effort to calm him down. It has been established by a functional analysis that this is reinforcing finger rubbing. Why is Philip engaging in finger rubbing?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Philip’s finger rubbing appears to be reinforced by receiving attention from his family such as them giving him hugs. Although, there may be other contingencies at play.
wrongAnswer: Philip’s finger rubbing appears to be a product of high anxiety, mixed with his family reinforcing the behavior by giving him hugs.
Anxiety is likely causing the behavior.
Being in stressful situations appear to be causing the behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: Although diagnoses may give a description of some behaviors, behavior analysts do not use diagnoses to explain why behavior occurs.

quizquestion.question: This occurs when explaining behavior, when the description of the behavior is the same as the cause of the behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: Circular reasoning occurs when the description of the behavior is the same as the cause of the behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: What is defined as “A fictitious or hypothetical variable that often takes the form of another name for the observed phenomenon it claims to explain and contributes nothing to a functional account of the phenomenon?
quizquestion.explanation: This is the definition of an explanatory fiction. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Frank engages in self-injurious behavior. He was recently diagnosed with depression. You conducted a functional assessment and have found that the behavior typically occurs when there is a lack of social interaction, and usually results in receiving high quality attention. You verify this with a functional analysis. What is “causing” Frank’s self-injurious behavior?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: A lack of attention appears to evoke this behavior, and it typically results in receiving high quality attention.
wrongAnswer: Frank’s recent diagnosis of depression is probably a contributing factor to why this behavior is going on.
quizquestion.explanation: Behavior analysts do not use diagnoses as explanations of behavior. The answer “attention” is too simple in that it does not explain the stimuli changes surrounding the behavior.

phase.name: Design and implement individualized behavioral assessment procedures. Conduct a preliminary assessment of the client in order to identify the referral problem.

quizquestion.question: What involves a variety of methods including direct observations and other indirect measures to inform behavior change programs?
quizquestion.explanation: Behavioral assessments involve a variety of methods including direct observations and other indirect measures to inform behavior change programs. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is a form of indirect assessments?
quizquestion.explanation: Indirect assessments are those which use data derived from recollections, or subjective ratings of events. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is a form of indirect assessments?
quizquestion.explanation: Indirect assessments are those which use data derived from recollections, or subjective ratings of events. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is a form of direct assessments?
quizquestion.explanation: Direct assessments are those which use information about the individual as it occurs. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is a form of direct assessments?
quizquestion.explanation: Direct assessments are those which use information about the individual as it occurs. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which assessments use information about the individual by observing the individual as the behavior occurs?
quizquestion.explanation: Direct assessments are those which use information about the individual as it occurs. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which assessments use data derived from recollections, or subjective ratings of events?
quizquestion.explanation: Indirect assessments are those which use data derived from recollections, or subjective ratings of events. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is an assessment/test that a BCBA may conduct?
quizquestion.explanation: BCBA’s are not trained to conduct IQ tests, competency evaluations, or diagnose Autism. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This behavioral assessment is a systematic method of assessment for obtaining information about the purposes a problem behavior serves for a person.
quizquestion.explanation: A functional behavior assessment is a systematic method of assessment for obtaining information about the purposes a problem behavior serves for a person. A functional analysis is a type of functional behavior assessment. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: During this behavioral assessment antecedents and consequences representing those in the individual’s natural environment are experimentally arranged as to determine behavioral function.
quizquestion.explanation: A functional analysis is a behavior assessment in which antecedents and consequences representing those in the individual’s natural environment are experimentally arranged as to determine behavioral function. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Design and implement the full range of functional assessment procedures

quizquestion.question: What are the four functions of behavior that are widely accepted as behavioral functions in applied behavior analysis?
quizquestion.explanation: Escape, Access (tangible), automatic, attention. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: You received a new client and are conducting a functional behavior assessment. You just gathered information through indirect and descriptive assessment. What should you do next?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Interpret information for indirect and descriptive assessment and create a hypothesis regarding behavior function.
wrongAnswer: Gather information through indirect and descriptive assessment
Test hypothesis using a functional analysis
Develop intervention options based on the function of problem behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: You should interpret the findings of the indirect and descriptive assessment. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: You just received a new client, and are conducting a functional behavior assessment. What should you do first?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Gather information through indirect and descriptive assessment
wrongAnswer: Interpret information for indirect and descriptive assessment and create a hypothesis regarding behavior function.
Test hypothesis using a functional analysis
Develop intervention options based on the function of problem behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: You should gather information through indirect and descriptive assessment. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: You just received a new client and are conducting a functional behavior assessment. You just gathered and interpreted data using indirect and descriptive assessment. You have a hypothesis of the function of the behavior. What should you do next?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Test hypothesis using a functional analysis
wrongAnswer: Gather information through indirect and descriptive assessment
Interpret information for indirect and descriptive assessment and create a hypothesis regarding behavior function.
Develop intervention options based on the function of problem behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: You should test the hypothesis using a functional analysis. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: You just received a new client and are conducting a functional behavior assessment. You tested your hypothesized function of the behavior, and received strong results. What should you do next?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Develop intervention options based on the function of problem behavior.
wrongAnswer: Test hypothesis using a functional analysis
Gather information through indirect and descriptive assessment
Interpret information for indirect and descriptive assessment and create a hypothesis regarding behavior function.
quizquestion.explanation: You should develop and select and intervention option based on the function of problem behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: During a standard functional analysis, which condition is used as a baseline to compare to the test conditions?
quizquestion.explanation: You should always use a control condition in a functional analysis to compare to the other test trials. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which term is synonymous with the term “Analog assessment”
quizquestion.explanation: An analog assessment (or analogue) is synonymous with the term “functional analysis”. (Cipani & Schock, 2011)

quizquestion.question: What is an advantage of functional analyses?
wrongAnswer: Provides a clear demonstration of variables that relate to problem behavior
Widely researched and reported in journal articles
reduces the need for and use of punishment procedures
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above are advantages. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which is NOT a disadvantage of functional analyses?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Reduces the need for and use of punishment procedures
wrongAnswer: Requires large amounts of time and effort
quizquestion.explanation: Functional analyses may reduce the need for and use of punishment procedures. This is an advantage of functional analyses. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is not an advantage of functional analyses?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Requires professional expertise and training to conduct
wrongAnswer: Provides a clear demonstration of variables that relate to problem behavior
Widely researched and reported in journal articles
reduces the need for and use of punishment procedures
quizquestion.explanation: Requiring professional expertise and training to conduct a functional analysis is a weakness. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Organize, analyze, and interpret observed data

quizquestion.question: You recently began implementing a new reinforcement program for teaching your client appropriate responses. You conducted a reversal to test the effectiveness. According to this graph, what should you do next?
wrongAnswer: Conduct a new functional behavior assessment
quizquestion.explanation: Implement the treatment again

quizquestion.question: You recently began implementing a new reinforcement program for teaching your client appropriate responses. You conducted a reversal to test the effectiveness. According to this graph, what should you do next?
wrongAnswer: Conduct a new functional behavior assessment
quizquestion.explanation: Continue implementing the treatment.

quizquestion.question: Describe the Trend of the following line graph:
quizquestion.explanation: This graph appears to be decreasing.

quizquestion.question: Describe the variability of the following graph:
quizquestion.explanation: This graph appears to highly variable

quizquestion.question: Describe the trend of the following graph:
quizquestion.explanation: This graph appears to have zero trend.

quizquestion.question: Describe the variability of the following graph:
quizquestion.explanation: This graph appears to have low variability.

quizquestion.question: Describe the level of the following graph:
quizquestion.explanation: Level is only determinable if given the value of the data points, or in comparison to another line.

quizquestion.question: Describe the trend of the following graph:
quizquestion.explanation: This graph appears to be increasing.

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is the most accurate visual analysis of this graph?
quizquestion.explanation: This graph appears to be increasing and low variability.

quizquestion.question: According to the BACB’s ethical code, how long are behavior analysts to keep records?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: 7 years (and as otherwise required by law)
wrongAnswer: 2 years (and as otherwise required by law)
5 years (and as otherwise required by law)
quizquestion.explanation: The BACB requires that records be stored for at least 7 years and as otherwise required by law. This is according to the BACB “Professional and Ethical Compliance Code for Behavior Analyst” section 2.11.

phase.name: Make recommendations regarding behaviors that must be established, maintained, increased, or decreased

quizquestion.question: You are working with a client who wants to lose weight. Why might you not select “weight” as the behavior of interest?
wrongAnswer: Weight loss is ineffective when the person focusses on weight
Weight loss is out of the competency of practice for behavior analysts
Focusing on weight will only make the person hungrier.
quizquestion.explanation: Weight is not a behavior. Focusing on other behaviors such as exercise and eating healthy will be more beneficial, however measuring weight may be used to show the positive effects of improved healthy behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This is a behavior that when changed, exposes the individual to new environments and contingencies.
quizquestion.explanation: This is a behavioral cusp. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This is a behavior, that once learned, produces corresponding modifications in other adaptive untrained behaviors.
quizquestion.explanation: A pivotal behavior is on that once learned, produces corresponding modifications in other adaptive untrained behaviors. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Teaching an individual self-management skills which results in the learner engaging in untrained behaviors, is an example of what kind of behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: A pivotal behavior is on that once learned, produces corresponding modifications in other adaptive untrained behaviors. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: A child learns how to walk, and now is able to come into contact with new contingencies that were unavailable until they could walk. This is an example of what kind of behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: A behavioral cusp is a behavior that when changed, exposes the individual to new environments and contingencies. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is NOT a question to ask yourself when selecting a target behavior?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Does this behavior match my research interests?
wrongAnswer: Is this behavior likely to produce reinforcement in the client’s natural environment after treatment ends?
Is this behavior a behavioral cusp?
Is this an age appropriate behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: When working with a client, it would not be appropriate to select a behavior simply because of a research interest. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is NOT a question to ask yourself when selecting a target behavior?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Which behavior, if addressed, will make your job easiest?
wrongAnswer: What adaptive behavior will replace the problem behavior?
Does this behavior represent the actual problem or goal?
Does this behavior cause any danger to the client or others?
quizquestion.explanation: The questions should revolve around the client’s needs, not the behavior analyst’s preferences. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Suzy’s support team set a goal for her to be able to read. However, recently she has been engaging in cursing as well as suicidal behavior. Which behavior should be the targeted first?
quizquestion.explanation: Behaviors that may cause harm to the client or others need to be addressed first. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Suzy has struggled for years with bullying other people. Just yesterday a new behavior arose. Suzy called somebody 6 times in a row on the telephone. Which target behavior should be of priority?
quizquestion.explanation: behaviors of concern that have been a problem longer take precedence over randomly occurring behaviors. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This effect on behavior occurs when an assessment procedure affects the behavior being assessed. Suzy knows a BCBA is doing an assessment, so her behavior changes.
quizquestion.explanation: Reactivity occurs when  an assessment procedure affects the behavior being assessed. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Design and conduct preference assessments to identify putative reinforcers

quizquestion.question: Stimulus Preference Assessments are used to identify:
quizquestion.explanation: Stimulus preference assessments are used to identify preferred (appetitive) stimuli. Appetitive stimuli are not always reinforcers.

quizquestion.question: All of the following are trial based methods for determining preferred stimuli EXCEPT:
quizquestion.explanation: Free operant observation can be used to determine preferred stimuli, but it is not trial based. Single stimulus, paired stimuli, and multiple stimuli are all trial based methods.

quizquestion.question: During this preference assessment, stimuli are measure consecutively, one at a time, and the interaction with the stimulus is recorded by the observer. Each stimulus is presented more than once, but the order is varied.
quizquestion.explanation: A single stimulus preference assessment is used by presenting stimuli consecutively, one at a time, and the interaction with the stimulus is recorded by the observer. Each stimulus is presented more than once, but the order is varied.

quizquestion.question: The BCBA presents a stuffed toy and measures how long the individual interacts with the toy. The BCBA removes the stuffed toy and presents a backpack and measures the interaction with the item. The BCBA removes the backpack and presents a spinner toy. What type of preference is the BCBA conducting?
quizquestion.explanation: A single stimulus preference assessment is used by presenting stimuli consecutively, one at a time, and the interaction with the stimulus is recorded by the observer. Each stimulus is presented more than once, but the order is varied.

quizquestion.question: During this preference assessment, 2 stimuli are presented to the individual, creating a forced choice of one of the stimuli. This is done repeatedly with multiple items, ending with every stimulus being paired with each of the other stimuli.
quizquestion.explanation: A paired stimuli preference assessment is conducted by presenting 2 stimuli to the individual creating a forced choice of one of the stimuli. This is done repeatedly with multiple items, ending with every stimulus being paired with each of the other stimuli.

quizquestion.question: The BCBA presents the child with a stuffed toy and a fidget spinner, and the child selects the fidget spinner. The BCBA then presents a fidget spinner and a backpack, and the child selects the fidget spinner. This is done repeatedly, varying the pairing of items. What type of preference assessment is being conducted?
quizquestion.explanation: A paired stimuli preference assessment is conducted by presenting 2 stimuli to the individual creating a forced choice of one of the stimuli. This is done repeatedly with multiple items, ending with every stimulus being paired with each of the other stimuli.

quizquestion.question: During this preference assessment, an array of items (3 or more) is presented to the individual. The individual selects an item. The item is then placed back into the array and the individual is again prompted to select an item. This is usually done repeatedly until all items have been selected.
quizquestion.explanation: A multiple stimuli with replacement preference assessment is conducted by presenting an array of items (3 or more) to the individual. The individual selects an item. The item is then placed back into the array and the individual is again prompted to select an item. This is usually done repeatedly until all items have been selected.

quizquestion.question: The BCBA presents 6 items to the child and says “Choose one”. The child selects an item, and then shortly after, the BCBA places the item back into the array of items. The BCBA says “choose one” again. Which type of preference assessment is being conducted?
quizquestion.explanation: A multiple stimuli with replacement preference assessment is conducted by presenting an array of items (3 or more) to the individual. The individual selects an item. The item is then placed back into the array and the individual is again prompted to select an item. This is usually done repeatedly until all items have been selected.

quizquestion.question: During this preference assessment, an array of items (3 or more) is presented to the individual. The individual selects an item. The item is then removed from sight, and the individual is again prompted to select an item. This is done repeatedly until all items from the array have been selected.
quizquestion.explanation: A multiple stimuli with replacement preference assessment is conducted by presenting an array of items (3 or more) to the individual. The individual selects an item. The item is then removed from sight, and the individual is again prompted to select an item. This is done repeatedly until all items from the array have been selected.

quizquestion.question: The BCBA presents 6 items to the child and says “Choose one”. The child selects an item, and then shortly after, the BCBA removes that item from sight. The BCBA says “choose one” again with only the remaining 5 items displayed. Which type of preference assessment is being conducted?
quizquestion.explanation: A multiple stimuli with replacement preference assessment is conducted by presenting an array of items (3 or more) to the individual. The individual selects an item. The item is then removed from sight, and the individual is again prompted to select an item. This is done repeatedly until all items from the array have been selected.

phase.name: State intervention goals in observable and measurable terms

quizquestion.question: You are teaching a class and creating objectives for your students. Which of the following is the best example of class objectives using observable and measurable terms?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: State the definitions of positive and negative reinforcement and use these principles in behavioral interventions
wrongAnswer: Learn principles of applied behavior analysis
Understand definitions of positive and negative reinforcement and know how to use them in behavioral interventions
Understand principles of applied behavior analysis
quizquestion.explanation: Intervention goals should be observable and measurable. Using the words “understand” or “learn” makes the behavior difficult to measure and observe. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: You are working with Jim who frequently engages in angry outbursts. What would be the best example of an intervention goal to address this concern?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Decrease the frequency of angry outbursts (as defined in the behavior definition) to three or fewer angry outbursts per session for 3 consecutive sessions.
wrongAnswer: Defined as not yelling, not shouting, not swearing, and not engaging in any property destruction.
To no longer engage in angry outbursts
quizquestion.explanation: ”Decrease the frequency of angry outbursts (as defined in the behavior definition) to three or fewer angry outbursts per session for 3 consecutive session” is the most appropriate intervention goal. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Intervention goals need to be established:
wrongAnswer: Once the intervention is in place
When determining the termination of services
quizquestion.explanation: Intervention goals need to be established before the intervention begins. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Mary is extremely disruptive in class, and does not accomplish essential tasks during the school day. Which would be the best intervention goal for Mary?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Mary will engage in fewer than 3 disruptive behaviors each day (as defined in the behavioral definition), and will complete 80% of assigned tasks each day for five consecutive school days.
wrongAnswer: Mary will learn to no longer disrupt the class and will accomplish all necessary tasks every day.
Mary will receive rewards for task completion. A DRO will be used to reinforce the nonoccurrence of disruptive behaviors.
Mary will engage in essential tasks during the school day and will no longer be disruptive during class.
quizquestion.explanation: “Mary will engage in fewer than 3 disruptive behaviors each day (as defined in the behavioral definition), and will complete 80% of assigned tasks each day for five consecutive school days”, is the best goal out of those options. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Prior to starting an intervention, what needs to take place?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Intervention goals need to be established
wrongAnswer: The client must decide which interventions would be best suited for themselves
The client will be quizzed on the intervention to ensure they understand the concepts
Intervention data will be graphed and analyzed
quizquestion.explanation: Before starting an intervention, intervention goals need to be established. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Before implementing a behavior change program, what must the behavior analyst do?
wrongAnswer: Describe the objectives of the interventions to the client
A risk-benefit analysis should be conducted on the procedures to be implemented to reach the objective.
quizquestion.explanation: All of these are discussed in the Professional and Ethical Compliance Code for Behavior Analysts. Section 4.05

quizquestion.question: Anytime new interventions are used, or new goals are established, what should take place?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Must obtain written approval from the client
wrongAnswer: Must submit the documents to be reviewed in a peer review
Must bill the client for each separate intervention to ensure the BCBA is not wasting their time
The client must submit a written review of their progress to the BACB.
quizquestion.explanation: Anytime new interventions are used, or new goals are established, you must obtain written approval from the client. Professional and Ethical Compliance Code for Behavior Analysts. Section 4.04

quizquestion.question: You consult with a family about their young child, and determine that their current living situation would not permit the effective implementation of a behavior support plan. What should you do?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Recommend that other professional assistance be sought (Therapeutic interventions, consultation, or further assessment)
wrongAnswer: If anyone can make a change, it would be a behavior analyst. You should do your best given their current environment.
You should assist them, however, using this as a research opportunity could improve the situation.
quizquestion.explanation: “Recommend that other professional assistance be sought (Therapeutic interventions, consultation, or further assessment)” is described in the Professional and Ethical Compliance Code for Behavior Analysts. Section 4.07. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This refers to the extent to which the behavior goal(s) and targeted behavior(s) will make a positive influence on the individual’s life.
quizquestion.explanation: Social validity refers to the extent to which the behavior goal(s) and targeted behavior(s) will make a positive influence on the individual’s life. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: You are teaching a class and creating objectives for your students. Which of the following is the best example of class objectives using observable and measurable terms?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: State the definitions of extinction and differential reinforcement and use these principles in behavioral interventions
wrongAnswer: Learn principles of applied behavior analysis
Understand definitions of extinction and differential reinforcement and know how to use them in behavioral interventions
Understand principles of applied behavior analysis
quizquestion.explanation: Intervention goals should be observable and measurable. Using the words “understand” or “learn” makes the behavior difficult to measure and observe. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Identify potential interventions based on assessment results and the best available scientific evidence

quizquestion.question: You conduct a functional analysis and identify that your client engages in property destruction with attention as a primary function. What might be an appropriate, function based intervention to implement?
wrongAnswer: Continue to prompt the client to complete their assignment even when problem behavior occurs.
Differentially reinforce the absence of the target behavior
quizquestion.explanation: Planned ignore is the only intervention listed above that is based on the function of the behavior.

quizquestion.question: You conduct a functional analysis and identify that your client engages in property destruction with attention as a primary function. What might be an appropriate, function based intervention to implement?
wrongAnswer: Conduct social skills training to teach the client a more appropriate way to gain attention
Reinforce every occurrence of the client engaging in appropriate attention seeking
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above are function based interventions that appear to be appropriate to implement.

quizquestion.question: You conduct a functional analysis and identify that your client engages in property destruction with escape from schoolwork as a primary function. What might be an appropriate, function based intervention to implement?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Continue to prompt the client to complete their schoolwork even when problem behavior occurs
wrongAnswer: Reinforce every occurrence of the client engaging in appropriate attention seeking
quizquestion.explanation: Escape extinction would be the most appropriate intervention out of the provided options.

quizquestion.question: You conduct a functional analysis and identify that your client engages in property destruction with escape from schoolwork as a primary function. What might be an appropriate, function based intervention to implement?
wrongAnswer: Continue to prompt the client to complete their schoolwork even when problem behavior occurs
Allow the client to take breaks from the task whenever they ask appropriately
Reduce demands placed on the client
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above are function based interventions that would be appropriate to implement.

quizquestion.question: You conduct a functional behavior assessment and identify that your client engages in property destruction with access to a preferred item as a primary function. What might be an appropriate, function based intervention to implement?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Frequent and time-based access to the preferred item
wrongAnswer: Restrict the preferred item to only being given to the client for 2 minutes each day
Provide frequent attention throughout the day on a time-based schedule
quizquestion.explanation: An NCR is an appropriate function based antecedent intervention. In this scenario, delivering the item frequently and non-contingently would be an appropriate intervention.

quizquestion.question: You conduct a functional behavior assessment and identify that your client engages in property destruction with access to a preferred item as a primary function. What might be an appropriate, function based intervention to implement?
wrongAnswer: Frequent and time-based access to the preferred item
Ensure the client does not gain access to the item immediately following the inappropriate behavior
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above are function based interventions that would be appropriate to implement for this scenario.

quizquestion.question: You conduct a functional analysis and the results indicated that the thumb sucking occurred during all trials including alone, play, escape, and attention at similar rates. What might you conclude from this functional analysis?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: The behavior is likely maintained by automatic reinforcement
wrongAnswer: The behavior is likely controlled by multiple stimuli
There was likely data collection error
There was likely an implementation error of the functional analysis
quizquestion.explanation: Automatic reinforcement appears to be the function because the behavior occurred during all tests including the “alone” condition where behavior is not reinforced by the behavior analyst.

quizquestion.question: You conduct a functional analysis and the results indicated that engaging in head slapping occurred during all trials including alone, play, escape, and attention at similar rates. What might be an appropriate, function based intervention to implement?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Teach him to clap his hands to mimic the same sensation as head hitting, without the same level of danger.
wrongAnswer: Continue to prompt task completion, even when they engage in head slapping
quizquestion.explanation: This behavior appears to be automatically reinforced. DRA procedure would be an appropriate function based intervention.

quizquestion.question: According to the functional behavior assessment timothy engages in kicking when he is asked to complete tasks as well as when he is ignored. What function based intervention could be implemented?
wrongAnswer: Continue prompting task completion regardless of problem behavior
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above would be appropriate interventions to implement

quizquestion.question: According to the functional behavior assessment timothy engages in kicking when he is asked to complete tasks as well as when he is ignored. What function based intervention could be implemented?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Provide breaks during tasks when he requests appropriately
wrongAnswer: Non-contingently deliver access to preferred items
A response cost program for kicking
quizquestion.explanation: Providing breaks during tasks when he requests appropriately is a function based intervention that could be part of the intervention package.

phase.name: Select interventions based on task analysis

quizquestion.question: What is a task analysis?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Breaking up a complex skill into smaller, teachable units.
wrongAnswer: A specific sequence of discrete responses ending with reinforcement
Various methods used for linking specific sequences together
Behaviors that may look different, but all result in the same reinforcement
quizquestion.explanation: Task analyses involve breaking up a complex skill into smaller, teachable units. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: What is a behavior chain?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: A specific sequence of discrete responses ending with reinforcement
wrongAnswer: Various methods used for linking specific sequences together
Behaviors that may look different, but all result in the same reinforcement
Breaking up a complex skill into smaller, teachable units.
quizquestion.explanation: Behavior chains are a specific sequence of discrete responses ending with reinforcement. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following tasks would be most important to break up into smaller steps using a task analysis if it were to be taught to novice learner?
quizquestion.explanation: task analyses are used to break up behaviors composed of multiple steps. Single step tasks would not usually need to be broken up further. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following tasks would be most important to break up into smaller steps using a task analysis if it were to be taught to novice learner?
quizquestion.explanation: task analyses are used to break up behaviors composed of multiple steps. Single step tasks would not usually need to be broken up further. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which is a research based method of developing a task analysis?
wrongAnswer: Consulting with an expert on the skill
quizquestion.explanation: Task analyses can be developed by observing a competent performer, consulting with an expert on the skill, or by performing the behaviors oneself. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: If you were to conduct a task analysis on putting on pants, which might be the first step outlined in the task analysis?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Select one pair of pants from the bottom drawer the dresser
wrongAnswer: Deliver one reinforcer as soon as the individual correctly puts their pants on
Select one pair of pants from the dresser and step in to the pants
Prompt the individual to put pants on.
quizquestion.explanation: The first step of a task analysis should be the first basic task necessary for the individual to complete. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: “Breaking up a complex skill into smaller, teachable units” is the definition of:
quizquestion.explanation: Task analyses involve breaking up a complex skill into smaller, teachable units. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: “A specific sequence of discrete responses ending with reinforcement” is the definition of:
quizquestion.explanation: Behavior chains are a specific sequence of discrete responses ending with reinforcement. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: When teaching a new skill to an individual, what can be done only after completing a task analysis?
quizquestion.explanation: Chaining can be completed only after a task analysis. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: In a behavior chain, conditioned reinforcement for the first step, should also be the ______ for the next step.
quizquestion.explanation: In a behavior chain, condition reinforcement for the first step, should also be the SD for the next step. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Select interventions based on client preferences

quizquestion.question: Stimulus Preference Assessments are used to identify:
quizquestion.explanation: Stimulus preference assessments are used to identify preferred (appetitive) stimuli. Appetitive stimuli are not always reinforcers.

quizquestion.question: All of the following are trial based methods for determining preferred stimuli EXCEPT:
quizquestion.explanation: Free operant observation can be used to determine preferred stimuli, but it is not trial based. Single stimulus, paired stimuli, and multiple stimuli are all trial based methods.

quizquestion.question: During this preference assessment, stimuli are measure consecutively, one at a time, and the interaction with the stimulus is recorded by the observer. Each stimulus is presented more than once, but the order is varied.
quizquestion.explanation: A single stimulus preference assessment is used by presenting stimuli consecutively, one at a time, and the interaction with the stimulus is recorded by the observer. Each stimulus is presented more than once, but the order is varied.

quizquestion.question: The BCBA presents a stuffed toy and measures how long the individual interacts with the toy. The BCBA removes the stuffed toy and presents a backpack and measures the interaction with the item. The BCBA removes the backpack and presents a spinner toy. What type of preference is the BCBA conducting?
quizquestion.explanation: A single stimulus preference assessment is used by presenting stimuli consecutively, one at a time, and the interaction with the stimulus is recorded by the observer. Each stimulus is presented more than once, but the order is varied.

quizquestion.question: During this preference assessment, 2 stimuli are presented to the individual, creating a forced choice of one of the stimuli. This is done repeatedly with multiple items, ending with every stimulus being paired with each of the other stimuli.
quizquestion.explanation: A paired stimuli preference assessment is conducted by presenting 2 stimuli to the individual creating a forced choice of one of the stimuli. This is done repeatedly with multiple items, ending with every stimulus being paired with each of the other stimuli.

quizquestion.question: The BCBA presents the child with a stuffed toy and a fidget spinner, and the child selects the fidget spinner. The BCBA then presents a fidget spinner and a backpack, and the child selects the fidget spinner. This is done repeatedly, varying the pairing of items. What type of preference assessment is being conducted?
quizquestion.explanation: A paired stimuli preference assessment is conducted by presenting 2 stimuli to the individual creating a forced choice of one of the stimuli. This is done repeatedly with multiple items, ending with every stimulus being paired with each of the other stimuli.

quizquestion.question: During this preference assessment, an array of items (3 or more) is presented to the individual. The individual selects an item. The item is then placed back into the array and the individual is again prompted to select an item. This is usually done repeatedly until all items have been selected.
quizquestion.explanation: A multiple stimuli with replacement preference assessment is conducted by presenting an array of items (3 or more) to the individual. The individual selects an item. The item is then placed back into the array and the individual is again prompted to select an item. This is usually done repeatedly until all items have been selected.

quizquestion.question: The BCBA presents 6 items to the child and says “Choose one”. The child selects an item, and then shortly after, the BCBA places the item back into the array of items. The BCBA says “choose one” again. Which type of preference assessment is being conducted?
quizquestion.explanation: A multiple stimuli with replacement preference assessment is conducted by presenting an array of items (3 or more) to the individual. The individual selects an item. The item is then placed back into the array and the individual is again prompted to select an item. This is usually done repeatedly until all items have been selected.

quizquestion.question: During this preference assessment, an array of items (3 or more) is presented to the individual. The individual selects an item. The item is then removed from sight, and the individual is again prompted to select an item. This is done repeatedly until all items from the array have been selected.
quizquestion.explanation: A multiple stimuli with replacement preference assessment is conducted by presenting an array of items (3 or more) to the individual. The individual selects an item. The item is then removed from sight, and the individual is again prompted to select an item. This is done repeatedly until all items from the array have been selected.

quizquestion.question: The BCBA presents 6 items to the child and says “Choose one”. The child selects an item, and then shortly after, the BCBA removes that item from sight. The BCBA says “choose one” again with only the remaining 5 items displayed. Which type of preference assessment is being conducted?
quizquestion.explanation: A multiple stimuli with replacement preference assessment is conducted by presenting an array of items (3 or more) to the individual. The individual selects an item. The item is then removed from sight, and the individual is again prompted to select an item. This is done repeatedly until all items from the array have been selected.

phase.name: Select interventions based on the client’s current repertoires

quizquestion.question: This is defined as all of the behaviors that a person is able to do.
quizquestion.explanation: The repertoire is all of the behaviors that person is able to do.

quizquestion.question: You have a client who engages in property destruction when prompted to get out of a task. The client has a limited verbal repertoire, and you have never heard her say the words needed to get out of a task appropriately. What should you do?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Use a simple action or a behavior she is able to do, to request breaks. Allow her to break from the task contingent on appropriate requests
wrongAnswer: Require her to say the appropriate words in order to get a break
Provide reinforcement every 5 minutes that she doesn’t engage in property destruction
quizquestion.explanation: It is important that the client is able to perform the expected behavior.

quizquestion.question: You have a client that never brushes his teeth. You have never seen him complete the task. You are trying to increase teeth brushing, what might you do first?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Implement a chaining procedure to teach how to brush teeth
wrongAnswer: Explain to the client how to brush his teeth to ensure he really knows
Require that the client brushes his teeth in order to earn access to 10 minutes of tablet use.
Require that the client brushes his teeth. If he is non-compliant he will be required to return a token from his token economy.
quizquestion.explanation: Implementing a chaining procedure to train the client on the skill will be a necessary component of the intervention.

quizquestion.question: You have a client that never brushes his teeth. You have seen him perform the behavior before, but during the last few weeks, they have been completely non-compliant. What might you do first?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Require that the client brushes his teeth in order to earn access to 10 minutes of tablet use.
wrongAnswer: Require that the client brushes his teeth. If he is non-compliant he will be required to return a token from his token economy.
Implement a chaining procedure to teach how to brush teeth
Explain to the client how to brush his teeth to ensure he really knows
quizquestion.explanation: There does not appear to be a skill deficit, rather non-compliance. A reinforcement program is preferred to a punishment program starting out.

quizquestion.question: You have a client who engages in frequent self-injurious behavior. The function appears to be attention from others. You have selected appropriate attention seeking as a replacement behavior. However you have never seen your client engage in any sort of appropriate attention seeking. What might you do first?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Use prompting procedures and behavior skills training to teach the replacement behavior
wrongAnswer: Deliver preferred items on a frequent time-based schedule.
Continue prompting task completion whenever the behavior occurs.
quizquestion.explanation: Use prompting procedures and behavior skills training to teach the replacement behavior.

quizquestion.question: You have a client who engages in physical aggression frequently. You have been hired to reduce this problem behavior. What appears to be the behavioral concern?
quizquestion.explanation: This appears to be a behavioral excess.

quizquestion.question: Scientists presume that the universe is a lawful place where things happen as the result of other events. This is which attitude of science?
quizquestion.explanation: Determinism is the attitude of science which explains that scientists presume that the universe is a lawful place where things happen as the result of other events.

quizquestion.question: Scientists continually question the truthfulness of what is regarded as fact. This is which attitude of science?
quizquestion.explanation: Philosophical doubt is the attitude of science which explains that scientists continually question the truthfulness of what is regarded as fact.

quizquestion.question: You hear about a new study that contains results contrary to what you have previously read. You demand to see the objective data because data are unbiased and open to anyone’s observation rather than the subjective belief of one single scientist. This refers to which attitude of science?
quizquestion.explanation: Empiricism is the attitude of science which explains that scientific observations are unbiased, and scientific findings do not depend on the subjective belief of the individual scientist.

quizquestion.question: Which attitude of science states that scientists have a basic strategy for finding knowledge? Events are observed with independent and dependent variables.
quizquestion.explanation: Experimentation states that scientists have a basic strategy for finding knowledge. Events are observed with independent and dependent variables.

phase.name: Select interventions based on supporting environments, environmental and resource constraints, and the social validity of the intervention

quizquestion.question: You are working with a child whose parents are going against the behavior plan between your sessions. This is having a negative impact on the child’s progression. What should you do?
wrongAnswer: Retrain the parents on the child’s behavior plan
Ensure the behavior plan is simple enough to be run by the parents
Identify in writing the obstacles you are facing for documentation purposes
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above are appropriate solutions to parents not running behavior plans. (Professional and Ethical Compliance Code for Behavior Analysts: Section 4.07)

quizquestion.question: This is defined as the extent to which target behaviors are appropriate, intervention procedures are acceptable, and significant changes in behaviors are produced:
quizquestion.explanation: Social validity is the extent to which target behaviors are appropriate, intervention procedures are acceptable, and significant changes in behaviors are produced. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: You are working with a child whose parents are going against the behavior plan between sessions. This is having a negative impact on the child’s progression. This is a concern due to:
quizquestion.explanation: This appears to be an environmental constraint. The child’s parents are part of the child’s environment. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: You are working with an adolescent, and teaching him appropriate dating skills. The parents ask you to stop focusing on dating because they don’t think the child should date until he is at least 16 years old. Focusing on dating appears to be a concern due to:
quizquestion.explanation: This appears to be a concern due to the social validity of dating as a target behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: You are working with an adolescent, and teaching him appropriate dating skills. The parents ask you to stop focusing on dating because they don’t think the child should date until he is at least 16 years old. What should you do?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Move the focus of your services away from dating for now
wrongAnswer: Talk to the importance of learning these skills to the parents
Focus on dating anyways. You are the behavior analyst and able to decide which target behaviors to focus on.
Bring in a neutral third party to select the target behaviors
quizquestion.explanation: It is important that the target behaviors and interventions have social validity. You should move the focus of your services away from dating for now. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: After conducting a preference assessment with your client, you determine that the most preferred item which should be used in intervention is more expensive than you or the parents could provide for the intervention. This appears to be a concern due to:
quizquestion.explanation: This appears to be a concern due to resource constraints. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: After conducting a preference assessment with your client, you determine that the most preferred item which should be used in intervention is more expensive than you or the parents could provide for the intervention. What should you do?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Use the next highest preferred item
wrongAnswer: Convince the parents to purchase outside their means because their child’s improved behavior is worth the cost
Use an intervention that does not require a preferred item
Explain to your friends the situation that your client is in, and ask for financial assistance.
quizquestion.explanation: You should use the next highest preferred item. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Scientists believe that all simple, logical explanations of the phenomenon of interest be ruled out before more complex explanations are considered. Which attitude of science is this?
quizquestion.explanation: Parsimony is the scientific attitude that all simple, logical explanations of the phenomenon of interest be ruled out before more complex explanations are considered. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: When selecting an intervention for your client, your coworker shows you an interesting study of a new intervention. This appears to be the only study on this particular intervention at this time. You are not interested in conducting research, so you tell your coworker that experiments need to happen more than once to convincingly establish a new intervention. Which attitude of science are you practicing?
quizquestion.explanation: Replication is an attitude of science that states that studies must be replicated to demonstrate convincing effectiveness. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Scientists continually question the truthfulness of what is regarded as fact. This is which attitude of science?
quizquestion.explanation: Philosophical doubt is the attitude of science which explains that scientists continually question the truthfulness of what is regarded as fact. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Identify and address practical and ethical considerations when using experimental designs to demonstrate treatment effectiveness

quizquestion.question: Which attitude of science states that scientists have a basic strategy for finding knowledge? Events are observed with independent and dependent variables.
quizquestion.explanation: Experimentation states that scientists have a basic strategy for finding knowledge. Events are observed with independent and dependent variables.

quizquestion.question: When selecting an intervention for your client, your coworker shows you an interesting study of a new intervention. This appears to be the only study on this particular intervention at this time. You are not interested in conducting research, so you tell your coworker that experiments need to happen more than once to convincingly establish a new intervention. Which attitude of science are you practicing?
quizquestion.explanation: Replication is an attitude of science that states that studies must be replicated to demonstrate convincing effectiveness. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: During a team meeting with your client and other team members, one of your coworkers makes a statement exaggerating your progress with the client. What should you do?
wrongAnswer: Leave it alone, but do not add to the exaggerations
Participate in the exaggerations to ensure continued funding
Correct the statement in an email to the team later on
quizquestion.explanation: It would be appropriate to correct the statement immediately. Behavior analysts avoid and correct false or deceptive statements. (Professional and Ethical Compliance Code for Behavior Analysts: Section 4.07)

quizquestion.question: Which experimental design might be selected if you are already implementing an intervention and did not collect baseline data?
quizquestion.explanation: B-A-B reversal is appropriate to implement and show experimental control when you have already begun treatment without baseline data.

quizquestion.question: Which experimental design might be selected if you are incrementally helping a client decrease smoking cigarettes?
quizquestion.explanation: Changing criterion design is used when incrementally changing a single behavior.

quizquestion.question: When looking at the graph of your client, there appears to be no clear trend in the behavior. You enter a trend line on the graph and there is a very slight improving trend that isn’t evident with a visual analysis. When talking to the client about their progress, what should you say?
wrongAnswer: Your behavior appears to be worsening
quizquestion.explanation: Behavior analysts are honest. If there isn’t improvement with a visual analysis, that should be stated to the individual.

quizquestion.question: Using experimental designs in practice:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Is essential to making data-based decisions
wrongAnswer: Is typically not realistic to do
Data collection is an optional practice in behavior analysis
quizquestion.explanation: Using experimental designs in practice is essential to making data-based decisions.

quizquestion.question: Which experimental design is depicted in this graph?
quizquestion.explanation: This is the delayed multiple baseline design.

quizquestion.question: There are several interventions that could help your client. You want to establish which intervention is most effective with you client’s current problem behaviors. Which experimental design could you use to compare different interventions?
quizquestion.explanation: Alternating treatments design is useful in comparing different interventions that may be effective.

quizquestion.question: What type of experimental design is depicted in this graph?
quizquestion.explanation: This is an A-B-A-B design.

phase.name: When a behavior is to be decreased, select an acceptable alternative behavior to be established or increased

quizquestion.question: What is something that generally must occur before selecting a replacement behavior to a problem behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: A functional behavior assessment must take place before selecting an alternative behavior to a problem behavior. Though, when using an incompatible behavior as an alternative behavior, a functional behavior assessment isn’t absolutely necessary, but is still recommended.

quizquestion.question: You conduct a functional analysis and the results indicated that engaging in head slapping occurred during all trials including alone, play, escape, and attention at similar rates. What might be an appropriate, function based intervention to implement?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Teach him to clap his hands to mimic the same sensation as head hitting, without the same level of danger.
wrongAnswer: Continue to prompt task completion, even when they engage in head slapping
quizquestion.explanation: This behavior appears to be automatically reinforced. DRA procedure would be an appropriate function based intervention.

quizquestion.question: According to the functional behavior assessment timothy engages in kicking when he is asked to complete tasks as well as when he is ignored. What function based intervention could be implemented?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Provide breaks during tasks when he requests appropriately
wrongAnswer: Non-contingently deliver access to preferred items
A response cost program for kicking
quizquestion.explanation: Providing breaks during tasks when he requests appropriately is a function based intervention that could be part of the intervention package.

quizquestion.question: You conduct a functional analysis and identify that your client engages in property destruction with attention as a primary function. What might be an appropriate, function based alternative behavior to teach?
wrongAnswer: Frequently deliver attention on a time-based schedule
quizquestion.explanation: Verbally requesting attention is an appropriate replacement behavior to a behavior maintained by attention.

quizquestion.question: Which procedure is used to differentially teach a functionally equivalent replacement behavior and decrease problem behaviors?
quizquestion.explanation: DRA procedures (Differential reinforcement of alternative behaviors) are used to teach replacement behaviors and decrease problem behaviors.

quizquestion.question: You are helping a child reduce the frequency of tantrum behaviors by implementing extinction. What might you do to minimize the extinction burst?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Teach a functionally equivalent alternative behavior
wrongAnswer: Deliver punishment contingent on the extinction burst
Deliver reinforcement during the extinction burst
quizquestion.explanation: Teaching a functionally equivalent alternative behavior may help minimize the extinction burst.

quizquestion.question: You conduct a functional analysis and identify that your client engages in property destruction with escape from schoolwork as a primary function. What might be an appropriate, function based alternative behavior to teach?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Request breaks using a “break card” program
quizquestion.explanation: Requesting a break using a “break card” program is an appropriate function based alternative behavior.

quizquestion.question: You conduct a functional behavior assessment and identify that your client engages in property destruction with access to his toys as a primary function. His toys are kept on a shelf out of reach. What might be an appropriate, function based alternative behavior to teach?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: How to climb up onto the stool to get his toys out himself
wrongAnswer: Move the toys on to ground level
Give him his toys non-contingently throughout the day
quizquestion.explanation: Although NCR and environmental accommodations may help, the function based replacement behavior in the answers above is teaching the child to climb up onto the stool to get his toys out.

quizquestion.question: Which intervention is used to teach an individual an appropriate behavior that is impossible to occur at the same time as their current problem behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Differential reinforcement of Incompatible behaviors is used to teach an individual an appropriate behavior that is impossible to occur at the same time as their current problem behavior.

quizquestion.question: Which differential reinforcement procedure decreases problem behavior without teach an appropriate replacement behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Differentially reinforcing other behavior does not teach an alternative behavior.

phase.name: Program for stimulus and response generalization

quizquestion.question: This occurs when a learner emits untrained responses that are functionally equivalent to the trained target behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: Response generalization occurs when a learner emits untrained responses that are functionally equivalent to the trained target behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This occurs when a learner emits the trained response in an untrained setting or situation.
quizquestion.explanation: Stimulus generalization occurs when the learner emits the trained response in an untrained setting or situation. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This occurs when the learner continues to perform the target behavior after the intervention has been terminated.
quizquestion.explanation: Maintenance occurs when the learner continues to perform the target behavior after the intervention has been terminated. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This is a behavior that once learned, introduces the learner to new contingencies.
quizquestion.explanation: A behavioral cusp, once learned, introduces the learner to new contingencies. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Mary learns to play Tuba during band class. She then plays the same song learned in band class on stage during a performance. Playing tuba on stage is evidence of:
quizquestion.explanation: This is evidence of stimulus generalization. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Jen was taught to wash dishes using a sponge. When a sponge was not available she washed dishes with a dish rag, without being taught how to use a dish rag. This is evidence of:
quizquestion.explanation: This is response generalization. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Jen was taught to wash dishes using a sponge while at her house. She is at her friend’s house and helps wash dishes. This is evidence of:
quizquestion.explanation: This is an example of stimulus generalization. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Jen learns how to walk, is now is able to reach on to the couch, gain access to her own toys, all because she learned how to walk. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: This is an example of a behavioral cusp. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: John is taught to kill flies with a fly swatter. He sees a spider and kills it with the fly swatter.
quizquestion.explanation: This is stimulus generalization. Killing the spider requires the same behavior as killing the fly, but the situation was different. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: John is taught to kill flies with a fly swatter. A fly swatter is not available and so he uses a shoe to kill the fly. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: This is an example of response generalization. Swatting the fly with a she is a different response. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Program for maintenance

quizquestion.question: This occurs when a learner emits untrained responses that are functionally equivalent to the trained target behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: Response generalization occurs when a learner emits untrained responses that are functionally equivalent to the trained target behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This occurs when a learner emits the trained response in an untrained setting or situation.
quizquestion.explanation: Stimulus generalization occurs when the learner emits the trained response in an untrained setting or situation. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This occurs when the learner continues to perform the target behavior after the intervention has been terminated.
quizquestion.explanation: Maintenance occurs when the learner continues to perform the target behavior after the intervention has been terminated. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This is a behavior that once learned, introduces the learner to new contingencies.
quizquestion.explanation: A behavioral cusp, once learned, introduces the learner to new contingencies. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: One way for promoting generalization and maintenance is to make the instructional setting similar to the generalized setting. How might you do that?
wrongAnswer: Randomly vary noncritical aspects of the instructional setting
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above are methods for promoting generalization. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Ella is learning job skills in a classroom. Before going in to the workplace, the instructor makes the classroom feel as much like a workplace as possible including many features of the jobsite in the classroom. This is an example of:
wrongAnswer: Randomly varying noncritical aspects of the instructional setting
quizquestion.explanation: This is an example of programming common stimuli. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This strategy promoting generalization requires instructors to randomly vary noncritical aspects of the instructional setting.
quizquestion.explanation: Teaching loosely requires instructors to randomly vary noncritical aspects of the instructional setting. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: While preparing to take the BCBA exam, you study thousands of practice questions to ensure you have studied enough possible variations of concepts to pass the exam. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: This is an example of teaching sufficient examples. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: What is a strategy for achieving response maintenance?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Ensure the learner is coming in to contact with reinforcement from the natural environment
wrongAnswer: Tell the individual that they need to keep doing well, even when interventions are not in place
Maintain interventions present throughout the individual’s life
Slowly increase the intrusiveness of interventions, such as increasing the amount of reinforcement the individual earns.
quizquestion.explanation: Ensuring that the learner is coming in to contact with reinforcement from the natural environment will promote response maintenance. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: What is a strategy for achieving response maintenance?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Slowly decrease the intrusiveness of interventions.
wrongAnswer: Tell the individual that they need to keep doing well, even when interventions are not in place
